item.title: Givan Lötz
item.description: Givan Lötz is a contemporary artist known for his pioneering use of encaustic (wax) painting. His gestural, non-literal “matterscapes” explore nature’s cycles of growth, decay, and renewal, expressing a dialogue between landscape and emotional response rather than literal depiction. Lötz’s work seeks enchantment and resonance in the natural world, creating a personal visual language that reflects both inner states and the regenerative rhythms of the environment.

item.title: Natasha Evans
item.description: Natasha (b. 1978, Zimbabwe; raised in Zambia) is a Lusaka-based mixed-media artist. She holds a BA (Hons) in Illustration from The Arts Institute at Bournemouth and works from her home studio. Her practice blends abstraction and figuration across paper, canvas, and sculptural materials like calabash, cement, and textiles. Natasha explores African identity, womanhood, and the dualities of existence, using metaphor, symbolism, and experimental techniques such as photographic transfers, mark-making, and layering. She has exhibited locally and internationally, including Paris, and continues to develop new work.

item.title: Puleng Mongale
item.description: Puleng Mongale (b. 1991, Durban, South Africa) is a contemporary visual artist working in photography and digital media. Her practice explores spirituality, identity, belonging, and womanhood, using art to process lived experiences and assert her narrative. Mongale’s work has been featured in exhibitions including Africa Foto Fair, Abidjan (2023); The Fold, London (2021); and Terrains of Possibility, Lagos (2021), as well as online and local group shows.

item.title: Jana Hamman
item.description: Jana Hamman is a South African designer, creative director, and artist working across digital, mixed media, and installation. A 2005 BA Information Design graduate from the University of Pretoria, she uses humour, irony, and satire to explore societal norms. Her practice balances personal curiosity and play with collaborative projects, creating work that entertains and engages audiences.

item.title: Wessel Hamman
item.description: Wessel Hamman (b. 1954, Pretoria) is a painter and designer whose practice explores clarity in visual communication. Using masking techniques, he creates figurative works reminiscent of stained-glass saints and Andy Warhol’s hero worship, portraying both cultural icons and anonymous faces. Juxtaposed with graffiti screen prints, his work interrogates notions of celebrity, accessibility, and relevance in an age of fast fame.

item.title: Eleven Editions
item.description: Founded by artist Bevan de Wet in 2016, Eleven Editions is a collaborative printmaking studio located in the historic downtown district of Ferreirasdorp, Johannesburg. As an artist-run workshop, we partner with a diverse range of South African and international artists to publish and develop innovative print and paper-based projects. Our studio has a primary focus on etching, relief printing, and various monoprinting media, with a strong emphasis on experimentation and combining different disciplines. We also host regular public workshops in techniques ranging from etching and marbling to bookbinding, fostering a wider appreciation for the printmaking craft. Eleven Editions is proud to have collaborated with many of the country's most respected artists, including Norman Catherine, Walter Oltmann, and Diane Victor. The exceptional works produced in our studio are regularly showcased at major events like the RMB Latitudes Art Fair, connecting our artists with a discerning audience of collectors.

item.title: Madlozi Contemporary Art Gallery
item.description: Madlozi Contemporary Art Gallery is an international, South African-based gallery dedicated to supporting artists across the African diaspora. Founded by curator, filmmaker, and cultural producer Beathur Mgoza Baker, the Black-owned gallery champions diverse cultural, racial, and gender identities, providing a platform for both emerging and established artists. Through exhibitions and events, Madlozi engages with critical socio-cultural, political, environmental, and humanitarian themes, collaborating with communities, non-profits, and creative partners worldwide. The gallery connects collectors and audiences to exceptional artworks, fostering appreciation, cultural dialogue, and the growth of Africa’s creative economy.

item.title: Sibusiso Gcaba
item.description: Sibusiso Gcaba (b. 1989, Johannesburg) is a photographer whose work spans multimedia, film, and photography. He studied at Market Photo Workshop, Umuzi, Skyrink Studios, and Through The Lense. Gcaba has exhibited locally and internationally, including the Yaounde Photo Festival (Cameroon), FNB Art Joburg Fair, and European shows in Gothenburg and Munich. He is a 2022 Tierney Fellowship Award recipient and participated in the 2023 New York Times Portfolio Review.

item.title: Dyman Gallery
item.description: Galleries specializing in contemporary art

item.title: OOA Gallery (Out of Africa Gallery)
item.description: OOA Gallery (Out of Africa Gallery), founded in 2013 in Sitges, Spain, champions contemporary African art and works with artists, collectors, and institutions worldwide. The gallery provides a platform for emerging and established artists to express their narratives and grow their practice. OOA hosts eight annual exhibitions showcasing African artists known for originality and freedom of expression. It has expanded internationally with a London space and, from April, an Olivella, Barcelona residency program offering accommodation, materials, and cultural exchanges to support artistic creation and engagement with collectors and media.

item.title: Dale Sargent Fine Art
item.description: Established in 2010, Dale Sargent Fine Art is a premier gallery and online platform specializing in fine South African art. For over 15 years, the gallery has offered an extensive collection of works by both established masters and compelling emerging artists. Dale Sargent Fine Art operates a private viewing space in Parktown North, Johannesburg, where visits are available by appointment. This is complemented by a robust online platform, offering collectors access to the collection from anywhere in the world. The gallery also provides a range of specialized services, including expert onsite consulting and personalized art sourcing for both private and corporate clients, assisting them in building and enhancing their collections with significant works.

item.title: David Krut Projects
item.description: Established in 2002, David Krut Projects(DKP) operates across Johannesburg with spaces at Arts on Main and the Blue House in Parkwood. It encompasses galleries, a bookstore, a publishing arm, framing, and educational facilities. The David Krut Workshop (DKW), founded in 2002 and now based at Arts on Main, collaborates with leading artists such as William Kentridge, Deborah Bell, and Maja Maljević to produce fine art editions and unique works on paper. DKP’s exhibitions showcase these collaborations and support emerging and established artists, while its training program nurtures future arts professionals.

item.title: Deepest Darkest
item.description: Galleries specializing in contemporary art

item.title: EBONY/CURATED
item.description: Established in 2007, EBONY/CURATED is a leading South African gallery with prominent spaces in Cape Town and Franschhoek. For nearly two decades, the gallery has been dedicated to showcasing contemporary and modern art from the African continent and its wider diaspora. The gallery is renowned for its well-established program, which is committed to both nurturing emerging talent and representing the region's most significant creative voices. Artists represented by EBONY/CURATED have achieved significant international recognition, with works featured in museum exhibitions and held in major public and private collections worldwide. A regular participant in premier art fairs such as Expo Chicago, 1-54 London, and the Investec Cape Town Art Fair, EBONY/CURATED is a key conduit between the vibrant art scene of Southern Africa and the global art market.

item.title: First Floor Gallery Harare
item.description: Founded in 2009 as an experimental, artist-run initiative in Harare, First Floor Gallery is Zimbabwe’s leading contemporary art space. The gallery combines commercial practice with artist development, education, and social engagement, and has been instrumental in launching the international careers of numerous Zimbabwean and regional artists. In 2020, it expanded to Victoria Falls, Zimbabwe’s leading international destination, to reach broader audiences and support emerging local talent. With its dual locations and dynamic programming, First Floor Gallery continues to champion contemporary art and nurture the growth of Zimbabwe’s creative community.

item.title: Gallery 2
item.description: For over 25 years, Gallery 2 has been a leading fine art gallery in South Africa, dedicated to showcasing contemporary artists and nurturing emerging talent. Founded as Gallery at the Square and rebranded in 2010, it is now based in Johannesburg’s vibrant Parkwood art district. Renowned for its dynamic program and artist support, Gallery 2 also offers expert art consultancy services for private collectors and major corporate projects. It remains a cornerstone of Johannesburg’s art scene, championing the creativity and vision of South Africa’s visual artists.

item.title: The Melrose Gallery
item.description: The Melrose Gallery – known as "The Gallery of the People" – is a leading Pan-African contemporary art space with locations in Johannesburg and Cape Town. Grounded in African identity, culture, and spirituality, the gallery provides a dynamic platform for artists, collectors, and the public to share stories and creative practices across disciplines, from visual art to dance, poetry, and music. The gallery represents iconic artists such as Dr. Esther Mahlangu, Mam Noria Mabasa, Dr. Willie Bester, and Pitika Ntuli, alongside emerging African talent. Hosting solo and group exhibitions, participating in major art fairs, and collaborating with museums and national galleries, The Melrose Gallery supports artists’ careers while engaging a global audience with vibrant and culturally rooted contemporary art.

item.title: mmARTHouse
item.description: Galleries specializing in contemporary art

item.title: LITTY | Contemporary
item.description: Galleries specializing in contemporary art

item.title: No End Contemporary
item.description: No End Contemporary Art Space is an artist-run gallery in Linden, Johannesburg, founded in 2015 by Maaike Bakker, Jayne Crawshay-Hall, and Dalene Victor Meyer. The gallery showcases contemporary South African artists across various media, supporting young artists and curators while encouraging both emerging and established collectors to invest in art, fostering a sustainable contemporary art ecosystem.

item.title: Association for Visual Arts
item.description: The Association for Visual Arts (AVA), with roots in the 1850 South African Fine Arts Society, is one of the country’s oldest art institutions. Renamed the Association for Visual Arts in 1995, it continues to foster cultural exchange and arts development, with its legacy tied to the foundation of the South African National Gallery.

item.title: The Artists' Press
item.description: Since 1991, The Artists’ Press has been a leading South African studio dedicated to creating the finest limited-edition prints in collaboration with artists. Founded by Tamarind Master Printer Mark Attwood, the studio specializes in hand-printed lithographs, combining world-class technical expertise with artistic vision. Our commitment to quality is uncompromising. Each original print is created on acid-free paper with the most light-fast inks available. To preserve the integrity and value of every edition, all works are signed and numbered by the artist, and the printing plate or stone is defaced upon completion. As a fully off-grid, solar-powered studio, we are also dedicated to environmental responsibility, demonstrating that world-class art can be made with a conscience.

item.title: Artist Proof Studio
item.description: Leaders in fine art printmaking excellence since 1991, Artist Proof Studio (APS) specialise in arts training, print collaborations, partnerships, sales and distribution of prints. APS is a multi-faceted community-centred organisation that trains talented students in South Africa and other countries in Africa. Our graduates are better positioned to become leading art practitioners in the market. Graduate and alumni artists are proudly represented through APS at art fairs, and reputable art galleries throughout the country and internationally. As a centre of printmaking excellence we attract opportunities to collaborate with prominent South African artists who work with our team of experienced printers to create exciting print editions.

item.title: Tumisang Khalipha
item.description: Tumisang Khalipha explores the impact of societal and industrial processes on human existence and the natural world. His work encourages reflection on humanity’s collective responsibility and the search for inner and environmental balance, highlighting the consequences of our actions on life itself.

item.title: manZArt
item.description: Galleries specializing in contemporary art

item.title: SMTNG GOOD
item.description: Something Good Studio is a collaborative textile design studio from Johannesburg, founded on the pursuit of a good life. We partner with artists and designers to create stand-out textile pieces that encourage well-being, happiness, and purpose. Our goal is to use art and design to make a gentle, positive impact on the world. Proudly made in South Africa from locally sourced natural fibres, our high-quality textiles are created in limited-edition batches to be enjoyed for a lifetime. Discover our collections online, via select retail stockists, or inquire about our custom design services for special projects.

item.title: 131 A Gallery
item.description: 131 A GALLERY is an independent art gallery in Cape Town, dedicated to showcasing the best of contemporary South African art. We champion both renowned and emerging artists, offering a dynamic space for discovery and connection. Visit us at our Sir Lowry Road location, where we host monthly solo and group shows in our main gallery and specially curated exhibitions in our Annex space. Beyond our exhibitions, we offer a suite of personalized services for collectors. We can help you curate the perfect collection for your home or office, arrange intimate studio visits with our extensive network of artists, and manage all local and international shipping logistics to ensure your artwork arrives safely and on time. Whether you are a seasoned collector or just beginning your journey, we invite you to explore the vibrant world of South African contemporary art with us.

item.title: Creative Block By Spier Arts Trust
item.description: The Creative Block, curated by Tamlin Blake, showcases 260+ South African artists, reflecting diverse stories and contemporary culture. Each artwork reflects a unique story and style, collectively offering a rich expression of contemporary South African culture.

item.title: Lizamore & Associates
item.description: Founded in 2001, Lizamore & Associates is a leading Johannesburg gallery known for its integrity and commitment to South African contemporary art. The gallery showcases both established and emerging artists, offering collectors a balance of innovation and investment value. With spaces in Parkwood and Rosebank, Lizamore & Associates continues to champion local talent through dynamic exhibitions and participation in major art fairs such as Latitudes, Turbine Art Fair, and CTAF.

item.title: Guns & Rain
item.description: Founded in 2014, Guns & Rain was among the first online platforms for contemporary African art, created to counter the continent’s under-representation in the global digital space. Now based both online and in Johannesburg, the gallery focuses on emerging artists from Southern Africa and beyond who engage with themes of identity, culture, and social change. Named after anthropologist David Lan’s Guns and Rain, the gallery reflects ideas of struggle, land, and transformation, offering a vital platform for the next generation of African voices in contemporary art.

item.title: 99 Loop Gallery
item.description: 99 Loop Gallery is a contemporary art space founded in 2015 and based in Cape Town, South Africa. The gallery operates on the belief that it should be a dynamic space for discovery—one that challenges convention and contributes to the evolving dialogue of contemporary art. It has a particular curatorial focus on painting and prioritises collaboration with both established and emerging local talent. Functioning as an accessible platform, 99 Loop supports creatives whose practices engage with intimate lived experiences situated within larger cultural and aesthetic contexts. Through its rotating exhibition program of solo and group shows, the gallery is a space dedicated to presenting fresh, subversive, and essential voices shaping South African art today.

item.title: Latitudes Online
item.description: Latitudes Online is a leading platform for discovering and buying contemporary art from Africa and its diaspora. Featuring a curated, ever-changing selection from galleries, curators, studios, and independent artists, it offers an accessible and engaging way to explore the continent’s vibrant creativity.

item.title: Doyle Wham
item.description: Doyle Wham is the United Kingdom's first and only gallery dedicated exclusively to contemporary African photography. Founded in 2020, the gallery launched with a nomadic program of exhibitions before establishing its permanent London location in 2022. The gallery is committed to celebrating photography in all its forms and, crucially, to developing the global infrastructure for this field. This is achieved through a dynamic program of exhibitions, international collaborations, and events designed to introduce new artists and build a robust collector base. Doyle Wham’s curatorial program has a particular focus on the intersection of photography with culture, fashion, art, and music, representing a roster of leading artists such as Angèle Etoundi Essamba, Trevor Stuurman, and Yannis Davy Guibinga. As a pioneering platform, Doyle Wham is a vital space for the celebration and promotion of the continent's most compelling photographic voices.

item.title: Stephen Langa
item.description: Stephen Langa (b. 1995, Limpopo) is a Johannesburg-based contemporary artist working in charcoal, watercolor, and oil. Trained at Tshwane North College and Artist Proof Studios, his work explores black experiences, personal journeys, and the intimacy of everyday life. Drawing inspiration from artists like George Pemba, Claude Monet, Gerald Sekoto, and Vincent Van Gogh, Langa’s expressive linework and emotive compositions invite viewers to engage deeply with his subjects and stories.

item.title: AKKA Project
item.description: Galleries specializing in contemporary art

item.title: Alon Skuy
item.description: Alon Skuy (b. 1981, Johannesburg) is an award-winning South African photojournalist and chief photographer for the Sunday Times and The Times. A graduate of The Market Photo Workshop, he has covered major national events, including the 2012 Marikana Massacre, earning multiple local and international awards such as POYI’s Photographer of the Year (2020). His long-term projects include documenting xenophobia in South Africa, soon to be published in book form with James Oatway.

item.title: Tessa Teixeira
item.description: Tessa Teixeira (b. 1969, Ermelo, South Africa) studied Primary Education with a major in Art at the University of the Witwatersrand (1991). In her twenties and thirties, she worked in housing and rural development, founding an NGO that built two schools and later serving with the Mineworkers Development Agency. Since 2006, she has focused on her art practice, pursuing further training in San Francisco and London. Her work explores existential philosophy, ecology, and climate narratives through mixed media, painting, installation, and printmaking. She has exhibited widely in South Africa, the USA, and Europe, including 1.5 Degrees (Berlin, 2021), What’s Next for Earth? (Stanford, 2021), Enviro Art Gallery (Duke University, 2021), Amref Artball (New York, 2019), Optimism (New York, 2018), Art of Lithography (WAM), and her solo exhibition Nothing Stands Still (Johannesburg Holocaust & Genocide Centre, 2018).

item.title: Matt Slater
item.description: Matt Slater (b. 1994, East London, Eastern Cape) is a photographer currently based in Cape Town, South Africa. He trained at the Cape Town School of Photography and works deeply with traditional darkroom and analog processes—film, photograms, bleaching, dyes—and experiments with “imperfections” (scratches, corrosion, chemical effects) to merge image and process. Slater’s art often explores themes of impermanence, transience, mortality, and nature. His key projects include The Arboretum (2017) and Efflorescent Cherry (2018), the latter published via Quiet Sun Books. His work has appeared in outlets like Od Review, Musée Magazine, and GUP Magazine.

item.title: Bonita Alice
item.description: Bonita Alice (b. 1962, Johannesburg) is a contemporary South African artist whose practice spans sculpture and mixed media. Her work examines humanity’s fraught relationship with animals and the natural world, exploring how ecological destruction mirrors social injustice and power imbalance. Trained as a sculptor at Wits under Peter Schütz, Alice works primarily in carved wood and in woollen dust on paper—a fragile, tactile medium she developed as an extension of her sculptural practice. Her imagery, influenced by Japanese, Chinese, and Indian aesthetics, often combines beauty and brutality to underscore the tension between violence and delicacy. After 13 years in London, she is now based in Cape Town. Alice has exhibited widely, with work held in major collections including the Johannesburg Art Gallery, Wits Art Museum, and the South African Reserve Bank. She is represented by Everard Read Galleries in London and Cape Town.

item.title: Jordan Anthony
item.description: Operating between Cape Town and Durban, Jordan Anthony (b. 1999) is a film photographer, curator, and arts writer who grew up in KwaZulu Natal and graduated from the University of the Witwatersrand, Johannesburg with a Bachelor of Art in Fine Arts. During her studies, she explored subjects in archaeology and psychology, including themes such as healing, dreams, and intuitive creation in her art practice. Anthony has since collaborated with various professionals in the local art industry, including the KZNSA Gallery in Durban (with Strauss & Co.) and Turbine Art Fair (via overheard in the gallery). Her interests also extend into philosophy, memory, and prehistory.

item.title: Zannele Libambo
item.description: Zannele Charlotte Libambo (b. 1997, Mpumalanga, South Africa) is a visual arts professional and cultural officer intern. She holds a National Diploma in Fine Arts from Vaal University of Technology and serves on the Visual Arts panel at the National Arts Council. As a curator and mentor, she has led exhibitions including Identify with Me and What Makes Your Heart Fly, exploring themes of identity, life lessons, and artists’ stories.

item.title: Billy Monk Collection
item.description: The Billy Monk Collection is the official and sole custodian of the photographic archive of Billy Monk. Operating with the full support of the artist's daughter, Collette Monk, the Collection is dedicated to the preservation and management of this unique body of work. Though physically small, Monk's archive is a vital and irreplaceable document of life in 1960s Cape Town, offering an unfiltered glimpse into a specific time and place. The primary mission of the Billy Monk Collection is to safeguard this important opus and ensure its legacy is preserved for future generations of researchers, curators, and art lovers. The Collection is managed by Gavin Furlonger and Craig Cameron-Mackintosh.

item.title: Phumulani Ntuli
item.description: Phumulani Ntuli holds an MFA in Arts in the Public Sphere from ECAV, Sierre, Switzerland, where he received the Prix-excellence for his research project Permutations of an Event, exploring archives, surveillance, and historical gaps. His multidisciplinary practice spans sculpture, video installations, performance, and artistic research, engaging diverse audiences while interrogating history, memory, and decolonial frameworks. Ntuli has exhibited and performed internationally, including the 2016 Kampala Biennale, Bone Performance Festival (Switzerland), and Act Festival (Geneva, Basel, Sierre, Zurich), and participated in residencies at Fondazione Pistoletto (Italy) and Alps Art Academy (Switzerland).

item.title: Thato Toeba
item.description: Thato Toeba is a Lesotho artist and legal scholar currently called flattendacurve (b.1990, Maseru). She shares visuals of continuing thoughts on personhood, politics, propaganda, nationality, globalisation, law and culture. Her work is influenced by her suspicion of formal things (culture law, politics, institutions,) as sober, objective, neutral tools in resolving growing crises of being here in the world today. She speculates on the intrusion of formal things in the emancipated joy of life, womb to tomb and fantasises about some kind of sweet chaos to be master in a less theorised life. She is a LLD candidate at UWC.

item.title: Sera Holland
item.description: Sera Holland is a designer and emerging artist based at the foot of Table Mountain, Cape Town. She is known for her thick impasto oil paintings, particularly her playful palette scallops made from leftover paint. Inspired by her natural surroundings, Sera also works with ceramics, creating, painting, and carving on the wheel.

item.title: Jo Rogge
item.description: Jo Rogge is a nonbinary multidisciplinary artist working in painting, printmaking, textiles, and sculpture. Their work explores displacement, family lineage, identity, and challenges heteronormative assumptions around gender and sexuality, using personal symbols and intuitive forms. Rogge also draws on experience in human-rights-focused design, having worked with UNICEF Namibia, ARASA, and WHO Namibia. They have exhibited widely, locally and internationally, and founded NJE Collective, supporting female and marginalized Southern African artists, with a current focus on queer narratives. Rogge lives and works between Namibia and South Africa.

item.title: Sylvester Falata
item.description: Sylvester Falata (b. 1985, De-Aar, South Africa) is a Johannesburg-based artist whose practice spans visual art and fashion. He began creating art at Mmabatho High School and later launched his eponymous fashion label in 2010, showcasing at South African Fashion Week and internationally. Falata’s work reflects his fashion background, emphasizing bold color, texture, and experimental proportions.

item.title: Nicola Taylor
item.description: Nicola Taylor (b.1984) is a visual artist from South Africa. In the context of belonging and connection, Nicola investigates natural laws and matter taking form. Using paint, animation, light installations and sculpture, she explores the human experience from a quantum perspective, looking at unity and identity at a level where manifestation is still physically undecided. Nicola studied in the UK, Italy and South Africa, she has presented five solo exhibitions since 2010, taken part in group shows and collaborations, attended residencies in South Africa and abroad and her work is part of private and public collections.

item.title: Alex Ayivi
item.description: Alex Ayivi is a French visual artist and printmaker, a graduate of Beaux-Arts de Bourges and ENSAV La Cambre (2018). In 2019, he held Fondation Culture & Diversité’s first residency at Cité Internationale des Arts, presenting his project La MUA. Of Togolese descent, Ayivi explores afrotopia, panafricanism, and family through vibrant works that capture both the exhaustion and serenity of daily life.

item.title: Lorraine Marcus
item.description: Lorraine Marcus is a South African fine artist with a 30-year career in expressionist painting. Her abstract and figurative work blends emotion, humour, and texture to explore personal experiences, loss, and human expression. Trained under mentors like Lynda Ballen, Phillipa Kotzen, and Gail Mechanic, Marcus works in pastels, oil, and mixed media, creating pieces that convey movement, gesture, and emotional depth. Her art reflects themes of family, maternity, culture, and travel, drawing inspiration from South Africa, Zimbabwe, Europe, Indonesia, and Australia.

item.title: L'MAD Collection x Latitudes
item.description: This collection brings together the diverse and powerful voices of: - Cinthia Sifa Mulanga - Shakil Solanki - Io Makandal - Maja Maljević - Jana+Koos - Olivié Keck - Pebofatso Mokoena - Puleng Mongale Shop the collection online at Latitudes or experience the pieces in person at Guillotine Design, 44 Stanley, Johannesburg.

item.title: Phendu Kuta
item.description: Phendu Kuta is a multidisciplinary creative, curator, and writer, and the founder of Unlabelled Magazine, a platform documenting contemporary African culture and identity through photography. She has contributed to Pan-African publications, academic research, and features such as Rising Stars in VISI, highlighting emerging South African designers and artists. Through Unlabelled, she shares visual stories, collaborates with creative teams and brands, and engages in arts and culture discussions on both local and global platforms.

item.title: Through the Lens Collective
item.description: Through The Lens Collective is a Johannesburg-based organization dedicated to nurturing the next generation of contemporary photographers. Established in 2018 and located at the vibrant Victoria Yards, we provide a crucial space for emerging artists to develop their skills, exhibit their work, and connect with a community of practitioners. Our offerings range from advanced photography courses and portfolio reviews to individual mentorship programs. We are committed to creating platforms for visibility, such as our annual Everyday A Woman social media exhibition, which showcases women photographers across Africa. The Collective has gained international recognition for its work, including a special mention at the Rencontres d'Arles Curatorial Research Grants and being featured in Lenscratch’s prestigious ‘Focus on South Africa’.

item.title: Jillian Ross Print
item.description: Jillian Ross Print is a collaborative printmaking studio dedicated to fostering connections between South African and Canadian artists. Owned and managed by Jillian Ross and Brendan Copestake in Saskatoon, Saskatchewan, the studio is a hub for creating innovative print projects, exhibitions, and educational workshops. With nearly two decades of experience, Jillian Ross Print specializes in collaborative printmaking, contemporary exhibition design, and arts education, partnering with artists, institutions, and galleries to bring unique creative visions to life.

item.title: Ilan Godfrey
item.description: Ilan Godfrey is a South African visual artist and photographer whose work documents the social, political, economic, and environmental forces shaping contemporary South Africa. He is best known for Legacy of the Mine (2013), which exposed the human and environmental impact of mining, earning him the Ernest Cole Award, and The Platinum Belt (2016), a multifaceted project on South Africa’s platinum sector. Godfrey’s work has been exhibited globally, including at the National Portrait Gallery (London), Iziko South African National Gallery (Cape Town), Wits Art Museum (Johannesburg), and Musée du quai Branly (Paris), and is held in numerous public and private collections. His photography and writings have appeared in The New Yorker, Le Monde Magazine, ZEIT, Guardian Weekend, and Financial Times Magazine.

item.title: Jessica Michelle Le Roux
item.description: Jessica Michelle Le Roux (b.1989, South Africa) is a visual artist working in bronze, ceramics, and digital media. She holds a BA in Sculpture and Printed Image from Tshwane University of Technology (2010). Her work blends 2D and 3D practices, exploring perception, generational thought patterns, and the ripple effects of human action. Known for her use of negative space, grounded figures, and vibrant textures, her art is held in local and international collections. She has exhibited at Investec Cape Town Art Fair, and been featured in Sasol New Signatures, Thami Mnyele, and Absa Ateliers Art Awards. Currently, she is developing her bronze series Senses and collaborating on Revolve: Redition Four.

item.title: Mwimbi Fine Art Gallery
item.description: Galleries specializing in contemporary art

item.title: Nomvula Millicent Hoko
item.description: Nomvula Millicent Hoko (b. 1996, Soweto, South Africa) is a contemporary visual artist working in painting, printmaking, and mixed media. Her practice explores identity, culture, and ancestral knowledge, creating ethereal, surreal works that bridge tradition and personal narrative. Nomvula is a member of Printing Girls and is currently studying Fine Arts at Walter Sisulu University.

item.title: Keiskamma Art Project
item.description: Founded in 2000 in Hamburg, Eastern Cape, the Keiskamma Art Project preserves local memory and oral history through large-scale embroidered artworks. The collective has received numerous accolades, including the BASA Award and the Chairman’s Premier Award (2011) for its extraordinary commitment to the arts. Marking its twentieth anniversary, the retrospective Umaf’ evuka, nje ngenyanga / Dying and Rising as the Moon Does at Constitution Hill, Johannesburg, brings together iconic works exploring themes of community, resilience, and healing. In honour of South Africa’s constitutional values — Equality, Freedom, and Human Dignity — the artists have created three limited-edition tapestries reflecting their hopes and lived experiences. Richly detailed and deeply symbolic, the works embody the power of collective creativity to heal and inspire.

item.title: Tshepiso Moropa
item.description: Tshepiso Moropa is a Johannesburg-based visual artist working in photography, collage, and film. Her practice explores identity and storytelling, often using Baroque-inspired techniques that combine dramatic compositions, bold ornamentation, and archival imagery to evoke emotion and tension. Moropa has exhibited internationally, including at Oakstop Gallery in Oakland, USA, and has been featured in publications such as 1854. Photography and The Mail & Guardian.

item.title: Onkarabile Nawane
item.description: Onkarabile Nawane (b. 1999, Mokgola, Zeerust) is a 24-year-old South African photographer specializing in conceptual, street, and landscape photography. Driven by a passion for storytelling, he uses his camera to capture personal and social narratives, translating memories, experiences, and emotions into visual stories. Nawane’s work transforms everyday moments into poetic, thought-provoking images that connect deeply with viewers and inspire future generations.

item.title: Sol T
item.description: Soliana (Sol) is a first-generation Eritrean-South African storyteller. Drawing from diverse life experiences, she explores the universal desire for peace, love, and being heard. With a background as a producer and scriptwriter in South African film and television, Soliana aims to create Pan-African co-productions, sharing Africa’s rich stories with the world and highlighting the continent’s creativity and resilience.

item.title: Lerato Nkosi
item.description: Lerato Nkosi (b. 1993, Mpumalanga) is a Johannesburg-based artist whose work explores womanhood, identity, and inherited teachings. Using ink and stamps as metaphors for authority and permanence, she examines how societal expectations shape the female experience. Nkosi is the winner of the inaugural ANNA Award and has exhibited widely, including at the Turbine Art Fair and Pretoria Art Museum.

item.title: Gugulethu Mnguni
item.description: Gugulethu Mnguni (b. Soweto, South Africa) is a Johannesburg-based visual artist specializing in watercolour, monotype, and linocut. She graduated from Artist Proof Studio in 2021 and is currently completing a senior program to further develop her practice. Mnguni has participated in projects such as Art in Action (2021), the ILRIG project (2022), a climate change initiative (2020), and recently exhibited at the Cape Town Art Fair.

item.title: Hemali Khoosal
item.description: Hemali Khoosal is a socially engaged, multidisciplinary artist and researcher based in Johannesburg. A Fine Arts graduate from Wits School of Art, she also holds a Master’s in Cinematography from Goldsmiths, University of London. Khoosal’s work explores human perception, gesture, language, migration, and intergenerational knowledge through collaborative video, installation, and performance. Her practice has earned numerous awards, including a Commonwealth Scholarship, the Sam Nhlengethwa Young Womxn Award, and the Giovanna Milner Award. She has held residencies at The Spinnerei, Leipzig, and the Bag Factory, and her work is included in collections such as the Centro Luigi di Sarro and the Jack Ginsberg Collection.

item.title: Farhana Jacobs
item.description: Farhana Jacobs is a self-taught Johannesburg-based artist, born in Durban and trained in Social Anthropology at the University of Cape Town. Her work explores women’s relationships with their bodies, surroundings, and the structures of patriarchy, presenting the female form as a landscape of contestation and imagination. Jacobs’ practice interrogates autonomy, narratives, and the unseen effects of societal systems. She has exhibited at Turbine Art Fair, Bubblegum Gallery, and AfricaNXT, and her work has been featured in publications including Creative Knowledge Resources and African Writer Magazine.

item.title: Fiona Davhana
item.description: (Dembe) Fiona Davhana (b.1996, Thohoyandou, Limpopo) is a multidisciplinary artist based in Johannesburg. She works across painting, doodling, photography, and writing, and is currently pursuing an Advanced Photography course at the Market Photo Workshop. Her work has been featured in publications including Afro-Punk (2016), Odd Magazine (2020), and Heavy Iridescent (2020). She has exhibited with the Through the Lens Collective in shows such as The Portrait Show (2020) and Everyday a Woman (2020), and will participate in Postcard Africa later in 2025. Davhana has completed workshops at MoMA, NEMISA, and Benrose Studios, and was recognized as a Design Indaba Emerging Creative in 2021. She has also facilitated talks, including the Last Thursday Talk for the Dior Photography and Visual Arts Award for Young Talents (2022).

item.title: Sinalo Ngcaba
item.description: Sinalo Ngcaba (b. 1996) is a Johannesburg-based visual artist from East London and Bizana. Self-taught in technique, she studied design in advertising at Umuzi Academy, where she learned about the creative industry. Working across oil pastels, ink, digital, and paint, Ngcaba explores black joy, pop culture, womanhood, and human rights, using art as a tool to tell stories and evoke change. She has collaborated with brands and creatives including Nike, Aperol Spritz, Comedy Central Africa, NATIVE Mag, and Piano People UK.

item.title: Everard Read Gallery Cape Town
item.description: Founded in 1913, Everard Read is Africa's oldest and largest commercial art gallery. For over a century, it has been a premier institution in the South African art world, dedicated to showcasing the country's finest contemporary artists. With seven distinct galleries across four key locations—Johannesburg, Cape Town, London, and Franschhoek—Everard Read offers an international platform for artists from diverse backgrounds. The gallery's mission is to support artists who are committed to contemporary storytelling, exceptional craft, and the making of meaning. It champions work that interrogates both universal and Afrocentric ideas, creating contemporary icons that inspire contemplation, introspection, and awe. Everard Read is committed to the long-term representation of exceptional, established voices while continuously seeking out and nurturing the next generation of talent, ensuring a dynamic and relevant program.

item.title: Philippa Allen
item.description: Philippa Allen (b. 1969, South Africa) is a Cape Town–based artist whose work draws inspiration from local landscapes. Using charcoal, panpastel, and acrylic layering, she explores the beauty, fragility, and persistence of nature, often manipulating surfaces to challenge viewers’ perceptions. Allen has exhibited extensively since 2003, with recent solo shows including Evoking Place (Sisonke Gallery, 2023) and Ghostscapes (AVA Gallery, 2020). Her work reflects on the intersections of environment, mental health, and human wellbeing.

item.title: Kay-Leigh Fisher
item.description: Kay-Leigh Fisher is a Johannesburg-based visual artist, curator, and publisher whose work explores identity, race, gender, and the process of unlearning in counter-cultural spaces. Her practice often extends into publishing as a form of curatorial intervention. Fisher holds a BA in Fine Arts from Wits University (2019) and an Honours in Curatorship from the Michaelis School of Fine Art (2020).

item.title: Cameron Platter
item.description: Cameron Platter is a South African artist whose vivid mixed-media works explore excess and consumption. Working across drawing, sculpture, painting, and video, Platter addresses themes of sex, beauty, politics, and violence with a provocative yet relatable approach. His work is included in the permanent collections of MoMA New York, Zeitz MOCAA, The Frac des Pays de la Loire, The Margulies Collection, and the Iziko South African National Gallery.

item.title: Ros Koch
item.description: Ros Koch (b. 1975, UK) is a South Africa-based artist whose work explores home, identity, and belonging. An immigrant, adventurer, and mother of three, her experiences inform her diverse artistic practice, which spans realism to impressionism. Ros has held multiple solo and group exhibitions, and her work is included in corporate and private collections worldwide. She lives and works in Stellenbosch.

item.title: Mulanga Mbedzi
item.description: Mulanga Mbedzi is a self-taught visual artist whose charcoal drawings explore healing, self-awareness, and identity. Centering the human figure, her work examines how emotional trauma shapes our self-perception and experience of the world, inviting viewers into a dialogue of honest introspection and personal truth. Holding an LLB from the University of the Witwatersrand and an Honours in Political and International Relations from Rhodes University, Mulanga’s academic background deepened her understanding of social issues. Her practice reflects a commitment to addressing their roots—captured in her guiding belief that “hurt people hurt people.”

item.title: Lusanda Ndita
item.description: Lusanda Ndita is a South African visual artist. In 2017 Ndita completed the Advanced Programme in Photography course at the Market Photo Workshop in Johannesburg. In 2020 he was awarded the Tierney Fellowship. His practice is one of self-investigation, experienced through the guise of cultivating his family's domestic archive of images, oral narratives and the inclusion of various artefacts, such as an Apartheid dompass book which belonged to his grandfather. His practice serves as a contemporary album which tells the story of his own heritage and life experiences

item.title: Khanya ZIbaya
item.description: Khanya Zibaya grew up a curious child, always inquisitive about his surroundings. This led to an early realisation of what he calls, “the chase of life” - that is, the multilayered and complex faces people wear in society. Zibaya’s passion for telling stories stemmed from unravelling these layers. As an alumni of the Market Theatre Laboratory, he creates photographs with his cellphone.

item.title: Leanie Barnard
item.description: Leanie Barnard Mentz, born in Pretoria and a graduate of the Open Window Art Academy (2004), is a multidisciplinary artist and floral designer known for her expressive large-scale paintings and drawings. Working with thick layers of paint and charcoal, she explores the fluid boundaries between reality and perception, revealing traces of the human condition through gesture, imperfection, and movement. Her work embraces ambiguity and emotion, reflecting on what we choose to reveal or conceal in a world obsessed with perfection.

item.title: Jono Dry
item.description: Jono Dry is a self-taught South African artist specializing in large-scale hyperrealist graphite drawings. Each work can take up to two months and 200 hours to complete, reflecting his meticulous approach and devotion to perfection. He produces limited edition Giclée prints from his originals. Exhibiting locally and internationally, Dry pushes the boundaries of graphite, using rich visuals and storytelling to emphasize the passage of time and the emotional power of his work.

item.title: Kirti Ranchod
item.description: Kirti Ranchod is a neurologist and brain health consultant based in Johannesburg, South Africa, with a special interest in neuroaesthetics and the impact of art on brain health. Her creative journey began at age eight, guided by her father, and has remained intertwined with her medical practice. Drawing on her cultural background and professional experience, Kirti’s art explores the intersections of neuroscience, creativity, and yogic science—examining how visual language and symbols influence perception, and in turn, shape reality.

item.title: Origin Art
item.description: Origin Art is dedicated to pushing boundaries and reflecting on global diversity and inclusion through art. The gallery builds a sustainable community of artists and audiences, fostering experimentation and collaboration across South Africa and internationally. By supporting artists as they grow and gain recognition, Origin Art aims to evolve alongside them, engaging across disciplines and partnerships to explore new frontiers in the art world.

item.title: Christopher Moller Gallery
item.description: Christopher Moller Gallery is one of South Africa's leading contemporary art galleries, founded on a passion for empowering artists and fostering meaningful artistic dialogue. Situated in a charming Victorian home in Cape Town, the gallery offers a unique environment where traditional and modern aesthetics converge. This intimate setting provides a nurturing space for artists to grow and for collectors to discover works of exceptional quality. As dedicated collectors themselves, the gallery's team is committed to showcasing artists whose work is relevant, thought-provoking, and impactful. They provide a highly personalized art buying experience, guided by integrity, artistic vision, and a deep appreciation for excellence. With an ever-evolving program of exhibitions available both in-person and virtually, Christopher Moller Gallery invites you to explore the power of contemporary art.

item.title: Bria Fernandes
item.description: Bria Fernandes is a Canadian figurative painter whose work delves into the quiet, often overlooked, spaces of the human psyche. Through her evocative portraits, she explores profound themes of introspection, silence, and the vastness of the unspoken. Her subjects are frequently depicted in moments of passive contemplation or deep reflection, their stillness acting as a powerful gateway for the viewer. By capturing these states of being, Fernandes masterfully examines the delicate nature of vulnerability, the subtle weight of oppression, and the hidden currents of consciousness that lie just beneath the surface. Born in Ottawa, Ontario, and now based in Winnipeg, Manitoba, Fernandes's artistic practice is shaped by a dedicated academic journey. She began her formal training at the University of Manitoba’s School of Fine Art, where she laid the groundwork for her thematic explorations. Currently, she is completing her Bachelor of Fine Arts at the Alberta University of the Arts, further refining her distinctive voice and the conceptual depth of her compelling work.

item.title: Chelsea Selvan
item.description: Chelsea Selvan (b. 1997, Johannesburg) is a South African artist and writer with a BA Fine Arts (distinction) from Wits. Her printmaking explores memory through fluid colour fields, calligraphic marks, and geometric forms that echo fleeting thoughts and architectural spaces. She was awarded the 2022 ABSA L’Atelier Award and presented her debut solo exhibition at Gallery 2 in 2024.

item.title: Nano Le Face
item.description: Ntwanano Shilubana (b. 1999) better known as Nano, or simply Le Face is a self-taught visual artist based in Pretoria. He studied Film Arts at Open Window and at AFDA. His work borrows freely from popular culture, and uses humour to mock, critique and parody our obsessions with love, consumerism, fame & ourselves.

item.title: Eugenie Marais
item.description: Eugenie Marais is a South African visual artist whose paintings depict everyday scenes—bridges, roads, and landscapes—imbued with nostalgia, serenity, and loneliness. Working in oil, acrylic, collage, drawing, printmaking, and mixed media, she often creates series that explore ideas, experiences, and emotions. Marais has held six solo exhibitions, participated in numerous group shows, and collaborated with The Artists’ Press on lithographs and mono prints. Her work is held in private and public collections.

item.title: Dela Anyah
item.description: Dela Anyah is a Ghanaian artist working across sculpture, painting, and installation. Using discarded materials such as inner tubes, tires, and license plates, he explores themes of decay, renewal, and transformation. Influenced by nature and fashion, Anyah weaves rubber into garments and assemblages that reimagine histories and speculative futures of neglected objects. His work is held in collections including the Celine Art Project, Sir David Adjaye, and the Institute Museum of Ghana. Recent exhibitions include Nubuke Foundation, Accra (2023), The Noldor Residency, Accra (2022), and group shows in Tokyo, New York, and Copenhagen.

item.title: Justin Southey
item.description: Justin Southey is a South African contemporary artist born in 1985, currently based in Cape Town. He graduated cum laude from the Stellenbosch Academy of Graphic Design and Photography in 2007 with a BA in Applied Design, majoring in photography. Southey's artistic practice is characterized by large-scale abstract paintings that delve into themes of nature, spirituality, and the unseen emotional and spiritual landscapes. His works often feature bold swathes of color, texture, and exuberant mark-making, creating a dynamic interplay that invites viewers to explore and interpret the underlying narratives.

item.title: Sunali Narshai
item.description: Sunali Narshai is a South African visual artist based in Montreal. Working primarily on paper, she combines drawing, painting, and collage to create bold, graphic compositions that explore diasporic identity, selfhood, and emotional aesthetics. Her work spans modern abstraction and figuration, seeking harmony through color and form. Narshai holds a BA in Fine Art from Rhodes University, and her work has been exhibited in South Africa, Helsinki, and at the New York Lift-Off Film Festival.

item.title: Buqaqawuli Nobakada
item.description: Buqaqawuli Nobakada (b. 2000, Western Cape, South Africa) is an emerging contemporary mixed-media artist raised between Philippi and Lady Frere, Eastern Cape. Working primarily with acrylic on laced paper, often incorporating custom clay or gold jewellery, her practice explores border crossings—both imagined and real. Nobakada is in her third year of Fine Arts at the University of the Witwatersrand and has exhibited in group shows including I Am & Nothing Else (Affinity Art Gallery, Lagos), Everything Was Beautiful and Nothing Hurt (FNB Art Joburg), and the SOMA exhibition in France.

item.title: Akshar Maganbeharie
item.description: Akshar Maganbeharie (b. 2017, Fine Art, University of the Witwatersrand) is a Cape Town–based multidisciplinary artist working across painting, drawing, and installation. His semi-abstract, impressionistic style reflects pop culture influences—Britney Spears, Starbucks, Kylie Jenner—while engaging themes of identity, cultural imperialism, and capitalism. A member of the Kutti Collective, he has exhibited in Autumn Salon (Gallery Fanon, Johannesburg, 2021), Kutti Bazaar (A4 Arts Foundation, Cape Town, 2021), and Apartment Vol. 2 (The Fourth, Cape Town, 2020).

item.title: FEDE Arthouse
item.description: Founded in 2020 by artist and curator Lebo Kekana, FEDE Arthouse is a nomadic gallery operating at the intersection of art, design, and culture. Through research-driven and site-specific projects, FEDE explores ‘space-making’ to create alternative, community-oriented exhibition experiences. Collaborating with platforms such as blank projects, Under Projects, and RESERVOIR, FEDE has presented exhibitions across Cape Town and internationally in Ibiza and Barcelona. Rejecting the traditional white-wall format, FEDE embraces a more experimental and culturally engaged approach, using exhibitions as a means to research, connect, and reimagine shared public spaces.

item.title: Samkelo Matomela
item.description: Samkelo Matomela (b. 1996, KwaZulu-Natal) is a Johannesburg-based artist trained at Artist Proof Studio in printmaking. Working primarily in painting and drawing, his portraits and figures explore vulnerability, emotion, and the experiences of young men navigating life. Using impasto and symbolic motifs like the butterfly, his work reflects themes of hope, change, and self-reflection, inviting viewers to engage imaginatively with his intimate compositions.

item.title: Khwezi Strydom
item.description: Khwezi Strydom, born in New Mexico to a South African father and French mother from Tunis, is a painter whose work reflects his fascination with cultural hybridity and identity. Initially drawn to graffiti, skate, and hip-hop culture, he developed a strong foundation in large-scale improvisation and letterforms. After studying astrophysics and training as a glassblower at Cristallerie Saint Louis for five years, he returned to painting full-time in 2012. Strydom currently lives and works in Drôme, France.

item.title: Motheo Mamabolo
item.description: Motheo Mamabolo is a South African interdisciplinary artist and curator whose practice explores the integration of the human psyche within the digital age. Working across culinary art, sound, and visual media, she investigates human existence alongside technological evolution. Her interests focus on food inequality in South Africa, systemic disparities amplified by private institutions in the 4IR era, and speculative art examining Africa’s role in spirituality and mental health practices.

item.title: Denzo Nyathi
item.description: Denzel ‘Denzo’ Nyathi is a South African designer, writer, curator, and creative. With a background in Communication Design from Rhodes University, he combines journalism and design to create work that speaks to society. Formerly an art journalist for publications like Bubblegum Club and Mail & Guardian, his curatorial approach explores connections between image, text, and space. His multidisciplinary practice spans visual arts, dance, writing, and design, reflecting a deep interest in how art illuminates human experience.

item.title: Gemma Hart
item.description: Gemma Hart is a Johannesburg-based curator, writer, and facilitator. She holds a BA Fine Arts (2016) and an MA in Contemporary Curatorial Practice (2020), both with distinction, from Wits University. Her research and practice explore the museum as a pedagogical platform, focusing on immersive exhibition-making, the ideology of display, and the lingering power dynamics of colonial legacies in contemporary museums.

item.title: Basadi Dibeela
item.description: Basadi Dibeela (She/Her) is a curator, DJ, and freelance arts journalist whose work bridges arts, innovation, and sustainability. Rooted in both village and city contexts, she explores critical cultural placemaking beyond metropolitan centers, questioning the roles of artist, curator, and community in shaping new cultural vocabularies. She is the founder of the Loselo Kultur Network in Kanye, Botswana, and has served on the board of the Kgosi Bathoen II Museum. Basadi holds an MA in Arts Journalism from Syracuse University and a BA in Political Science from the University of Botswana.

item.title: Carina Ubisse Capitine
item.description: Carina Ubisse Capitine is a Mozambican artivist and communications professional who uses art to amplify marginalized voices and drive social change. Her work explores self-reflection, pleasure, and identity in resistance to the invisibilization and objectification of women. As a curator, she focuses on creating access for underrepresented artists and promoting Afro-centric aesthetics. A Fulbright Scholar, she holds a Master’s in Communication and Development Studies from Ohio University and a Licenciatura in Communication Sciences from Universidade Politécnica in Mozambique.

item.title: Jadesola Olaniyan
item.description: Jadesola Olaniyan (b. 1997) is a Lagos-based visual artist, independent curator, and anthropologist. A graduate of the University of British Columbia, her work spans collections-based research and exhibitions with institutions such as the Museum of Anthropology and SMO Contemporary Art. Guided by theories of memory and consciousness, Olaniyan explores how art extends beyond gallery spaces, using collaborative approaches to address challenges faced by artists and communities.

item.title: Kezia Owusu-Ankomah
item.description: Kezia Ouomoye Owusu-Ankomah is a Ph.D. candidate in Painting and Sculpture, and an art practitioner, curator, writer, and mentor based in Accra, Ghana. She manages ADA Contemporary Art Gallery and has curated numerous exhibitions, including Monologue of Voices and Hulu Shinyoo. She also serves as Operations Advisor at The African Art Hub UK, contributing to the development of African contemporary art locally and internationally.

item.title: Jason Langa
item.description: Jason Langa (b.1997, Johannesburg) is a South African figurative painter and printmaker. Using oil paint and print techniques, he explores nostalgia, identity, memory, and self-discovery. Influenced by Impressionism, his work features expressive brushwork, ethereal blue skin tones, clouds, and closed eyes, evoking introspection and blurring the boundaries between past and present.

item.title: Motlhoki Nono
item.description: Motlhoki Nono (b. 1998, Mabopane, Pretoria) is a Johannesburg-based artist whose work explores the intimate and violent politics of romantic love. Working across video, photography, and printmaking, she investigates how love manifests at the intersection of race, class, and gender. Her practice reflects a decolonial and sociological enquiry into black love—its complexities, domestic spaces, and emotional landscapes. Nono completed her Honours in Fine Art at the University of the Witwatersrand, graduating with five distinctions and two awards.

item.title: Hlobile Dube
item.description: Hlobile Maphumulo (b. 1996, eNanda, South Africa) is a visual artist based in Durban. She studied Art and Design (N4–N6) and gained experience at various art centers and the BAT Center. In 2022, Hlobile transitioned to painting, blending her graphic design background with vibrant, expressive colors. Her work is not focused on realism but on conveying emotion, spirituality, and healing through color, exploring the energy and meaning each hue can hold.

item.title: Xhanti Zwelendaba
item.description: Xhanti Zwelendaba is a multidisciplinary artist working across sculpture, printmaking, installation, performance, and video. His practice explores the tensions between Xhosa traditions, capitalism, and nationalism, while confronting the lasting effects of colonialism and apartheid. He has exhibited widely, including at the Investec Cape Town Art Fair, FNB Art Joburg, and Turbine Art Fair (Artist of the Year, 2021), and recently completed a residency at the Leipzig International Art Programme in Germany.

item.title: Warren_Maroon
item.description: Warren Maroon (b. 1985) is a Cape Town-based artist and sculptor. Growing up in Mitchell’s Plain on the Cape Flats, Maroon turned to art as a means of escape and expression. Drawing inspiration from an Arte Povera aesthetic, he uses found objects to create sculptural works that reflect on identity, inequality, and lived experiences as a person of colour in South Africa.

item.title: Gaelen Pinnock
item.description: Gaelen Pinnock (b.1980, South Africa) is a Cape Town-based artist whose work explores power, domesticity, and division within urban landscapes. Originally trained as an architect, Pinnock examines how modern developments and apartheid legacies shape social and spatial inequalities. Using found objects and materials—like security equipment and construction remnants—his work distills patterns of exclusion and tension into stark, conceptual pieces. He has exhibited locally and internationally, including at Zeitz MOCAA, A4 Arts Foundation, and the Rupert Museum.

item.title: Lebogang Mogul Mabusela
item.description: Lebogang Mogul Mabusela, born in Mabopane, is a self-proclaimed Zinequeen and Monotypebabe whose practice explores the male form. A Wits Fine Arts graduate (2019) and recipient of the Standard Bank Fine Arts Prize, Mabusela has exhibited widely across South Africa and internationally, including at Frieze London and Lagos. Her debut solo exhibition, Ukwatile? (2022) at Stevenson Gallery, examined language, catcalling, and voyeurism. She currently runs The Monotypebabe Curatorial, a printmaking initiative supporting emerging artists.

item.title: Maja Maljević
item.description: Maja Maljević (b. 1973, Belgrade, Serbia) is a Johannesburg-based artist who moved to South Africa in 2000. She holds an MFA from the University of Belgrade (1999). Her work is rooted in gestural abstraction, starting by “dirtying” the canvas with bright layers of paint and building complex surfaces of drips, blocks, and waves of color. Maljević emphasizes physical movement in her process, creating dynamic compositions that balance conflict and harmony. Working across painting, printmaking, and sculpture, she reinterprets Modernist techniques to suit contemporary needs, aiming for coherence and interplay between all elements in her work.

item.title: Alexandra Naledi Holtman
item.description: Alexandra Naledi Holtman is a Cape Town-based interdisciplinary artist and graduate of the Michaelis School of Fine Art (UCT). Working across sound, sculpture, and interactive installation, her practice explores communication, connection, and perception. Through playful yet conceptually grounded works—such as her interactive sound installation inspired by Roy Ascott’s theory of telematics—Holtman reimagines digital communication through tactile, lo-fi materials. By translating high-tech ideas into intimate, physical encounters, she invites audiences to reflect on the essence of human connection in an increasingly digital world.

item.title: Cazlynne Peffer
item.description: Cazlynne Peffer – Muffled Violations (2022) is a sculptural and video-based series exploring sexual trauma through found and used objects, including duvets, chairs, and pantyhose. The works embody the intimate effects of rape, using bodily engagement with materials to convey the lingering impact of trauma. Pantyhose, in particular, references both the body and childhood experiences of boundary-based games, linking notions of consent and violation. Through this practice, Peffer transforms everyday objects into vessels of memory and protest, creating a space for empathy, reflection, and alternative narratives of sexual violence within the South African context. The series acts as a personal and social reckoning, reclaiming meaning and opening paths for healing.

item.title: Mika Márffy
item.description: Zambian-based abstract painter Mika Márffy is inspired by symbolic, transformative change and growth as informed by the unconscious. Mika’s intuitive process-based artworks are layered with meaning, translating energy and emotion and forming a narrative of life beyond what the eye can see. The ‘Sacred Feminine/ Sophia’ is a continual theme in her work.

item.title: Amira Shariff
item.description: Amira Shariff (b. 1999, Johannesburg) is an artist, art director, strategist, and cultural curator who primarily works with photography. Currently completing her degree in Strategic Brand Communications at Vega, she also works as a creative strategist in agency and events. A graduate of the Market Photo Workshop (2019) and Through the Lens Collective (2020), her work has been shown at the FNB Art Fair (2022), Berman Contemporary (2021), and the TTL Collective Portrait Show (2020). Inspired by her late uncle, Abdul Shariff, her practice explores identity, connection, and disconnection through layered images that challenge perception.

item.title: DAPAAH Gallery
item.description: Dapaah Gallery is a premier art agency and consultancy specializing in contemporary art from Africa and its global diasporas.The gallery provides expert, assured advice to a diverse clientele, including emerging and established collectors, patrons, and institutions, guiding them in building significant collections. Simultaneously, Dapaah Gallery is dedicated to promoting a curated roster of the most exciting and gifted visual artists of African heritage from around the world, working to elevate their careers and connect their work with a global audience. Positioned at the intersection of advisory and artist representation, Dapaah Gallery is a trusted partner for anyone passionate about the dynamic landscape of art from Africa and its diaspora.

item.title: Kulungwana Art Gallery
item.description: Kulungwana has organized solo and collective art exhibitions, including, painting, sculpture, ceramics and photography. The space has also hosted the launching of books and concerts

item.title: MOVART
item.description: MOVART was founded in 2015 to promote contemporary African art and works by artists from the African and Portuguese-speaking diasporas. With spaces in Luanda (residencies and talent development) and Lisbon (exhibitions and international exposure), the gallery represents artists like IHOSVANNY, KEYEZUA, KWAME SOUSA, MÁRIO MACILAU, RITA GT, and THÓ SIMOES. MOVART participates in major international fairs and offers consultancy for private and corporate collections while producing cultural projects across Africa and Europe.

item.title: Reservoir
item.description: RESERVOIR, founded in 2021 by Heinrich Groenewald and Shona van der Merwe, is a Cape Town-based gallery and curatorial platform. It hosts solo exhibitions, participates in major international art fairs—including Investec Cape Town, ARCO Madrid, SPARK Vienna, and Artissima Turin—and has won awards such as the Investec Emerging Artist Award and Fundación Banco Sabadell Young Talent Award. The gallery also curates collaborative projects, including Mother City (2024), Disrupting the Dream (2025), Spaced Out (Berlin, 2024), and Fallow Ground (Germany, 2024).

item.title: White River Gallery
item.description: White River Gallery, established in 2008 and directed by Dana MacFarlane, is a distinctive visual arts platform in the Lowveld. Showcasing contemporary fine art from Mpumalanga as well as broader South and Southern African artists, the gallery highlights regional creativity and the cultural significance of art as social, political, and evolutionary expression. Merging with Halifax Art in 2017, White River Gallery emphasizes personal engagement with clients and collectors, fostering transformative experiences through art.

item.title: Imba Ya Sarai Gallery
item.description: Imba Ya Sarai is a contemporary art gallery dedicated to showcasing artists from Africa and its global diaspora. Founded to address the challenges faced by even seasoned artists in securing representation, the gallery provides a vital platform for established and emerging voices alike. Through its commitment to inclusivity and sustainability, Imba Ya Sarai connects important African artists with new audiences and collectors, ensuring their continued influence in contemporary art.

item.title: Thato Tlatsi
item.description: Tshegofatso Tlatsi (b. 1999, Johannesburg) is a visual artist based in Roodepoort, South Africa. She holds a BA in Fine Arts from the University of Johannesburg (2022) and works primarily in drawing and painting using ink, charcoal, chalk, and acrylic on canvas. Tlatsi’s practice is deeply personal, exploring themes of black femininity, sexuality, mental health, and the complexities of existence. She is particularly drawn to mark-making, embracing the unpredictability of ink and charcoal as metaphors for life, and uses her work to reflect on the interplay between agony, beauty, and free will.

item.title: ReCurate
item.description: Renée Eisen-Khonat is an independent curator and artist based in Gaborone, Botswana, and runs Recurate, a platform dedicated to promoting female, feminist, and emerging contemporary artists. Her experience as an artist informs her curatorial practice, allowing her to understand and support each artist’s unique process. With over 20 years in Botswana’s art scene—as a gallerist, facilitator, and teacher—she is committed to amplifying female artistic voices and developing both artists’ careers and the country’s art market.

item.title: Nada Baraka
item.description: Nada Baraka (b. 1990) is a Cairo-based visual artist with a BA in Communication Media Art and Fine Arts from the American University in Cairo and an MFA from Central Saint Martins, London. Her work has been exhibited in London, Paris, Lisbon, and across Cairo, including Gypsum Gallery, Mashrabia Gallery, Darb 1718, and Medrar, and she won first prize in Mohamad Abla’s painting competition in 2015. Baraka’s paintings oscillate between abstraction and surrealism, using vivid colors and expressive brushwork to explore emotional fluctuations and the absurd. Her work often features distorted forms, body parts, and layered compositions, emphasizing fluidity and eruption as a way to narrate complex experiences.

item.title: Sethembile Msezane
item.description: Sethembile Msezane (b. 1991, KwaZulu-Natal) is a Cape Town-based interdisciplinary artist working across photography, painting, live performance, film, sculpture, and installation. Her work explores spirituality, commemoration, African knowledge systems, and the absence of the black female body in historical narratives. Msezane has exhibited widely in South Africa and internationally, including Zeitz MOCAA, Iziko South African National Gallery, The Royal Ontario Museum, and Oscar Niemeyer Museum. She holds an MFA from Michaelis School of Fine Art, UCT, and has participated in residencies, biennales, and received awards including the Rising Light award at the Mbokodo Awards (2016) and recognition as an OkayAfrica 100 Women Honoree (2018).

item.title: Christine Dixie
item.description: Christine Dixie is an established South African artist whose work explores gender roles, myth, and Europe’s colonial legacy in Africa. Based in Makhanda, she draws on archival imagery and research to create haunting visual narratives that blur the boundaries between past and present. Primarily a printmaker, Dixie often extends her works through embossing, embroidery, books, film, and installation, reflecting her interest in the interplay between text and image. Her art forms part of major collections including The New York Public Library, The Smithsonian National Museum of African Art, The Iwalewahaus Museum, Standard Bank Gallery, Johannesburg Art Gallery, and Iziko South African National Gallery.

item.title: Bontle Juku
item.description: Bontle Juku is a South African multidisciplinary artist whose practice spans painting, photography, drawing, and experimental film. Her work explores the past and present of Black existence through themes of world-building, spirituality, and socio-political reflection. Using photographic lighting, self-portraiture, and abstraction, Juku creates emotive imagery that reclaims the representation of the Black body with dignity and humanity. Her work is inspired by everyday life, social issues, music, film, and personal experience.

item.title: Phila Hillie
item.description: Phila Hillie is a multidisciplinary South African artist whose work is inspired by women, culture, and space. Drawing from her background in architecture, digital art, and UI/UX, she explores storytelling, composition, and new media to create spaces—both physical and digital—where women are celebrated and seen.

item.title: Buhle Nkalashe
item.description: Buhle Nkalashe (b. 1994, South Africa) is a Cape Town-based painter and mixed-media artist working with oil, acrylic, and oil pastels. He holds a BA in Graphic Design from the Cape Town Creative Academy (2018) and transitioned from advertising to full-time visual arts in 2019. Nkalashe draws inspiration from South African cultural ceremonies, particularly Xhosa traditions, using vibrant patterns and colors from Xhosa, Zulu, and Ndebele heritage to create contemporary, hybrid interpretations of African identity.

item.title: Imaan Latif
item.description: Imaan Latif is a Johannesburg-based multidimensional artist whose practice spans abstract painting, performance, cultural critique, and playwriting. She is also a personal trainer, spiritual scientist, and Kundalini yoga teacher, working at the intersection of art, academia, and wellness.

item.title: Thero Makepe
item.description: Thero Makepe (b. 1996, Gaborone, Botswana) is a visual artist whose work reflects personal and societal narratives shaped by his upbringing in Botswana and South Africa. A 2019 BA Photography graduate from the Michaelis School of Fine Art (UCT), Makepe has since gained international recognition, receiving awards and residencies including the Prince Claus Seed Award (2024), FOAM Talent (2024-2025), and the Tierney Fellowship Award (2019). His practice spans photography and multimedia projects, exploring identity, memory, and collective experience. Makepe has presented solo exhibitions such as We Didn’t Choose to Be Down Here (Lemkus Gallery, 2025) and It’s Not Going to Get Better (Vela Projects, 2024–25), alongside participation in prominent group shows locally and abroad, including Art Basel NY and the Botswana Pavilion projects. His work is held in private and public collections, including the University of Cape Town and University of Pretoria. Makepe is a founding member of the Botswana Pavilion collective and works between Gaborone, Cape Town, and Johannesburg.

item.title: Candice Myataza
item.description: Candice Myataza (b. 1997, Cape Town) is a South African visual artist whose work explores racial belonging and shared human identity. As a mixed-race individual, her paintings reflect on inclusion, community, and the commonalities that connect people beyond race. Graduating with a BA in Film, Anthropology, and Sociology from the University of Cape Town (2021), she works primarily in acrylics, oil, and mixed media on canvas. Myataza has exhibited at Mullers Gallery, 6 Spin Street Gallery, 91 Loop Street Gallery, and Red Gallery in Cape Town, and has sold over 20 paintings. Her style emphasizes earthy tones and intricate line work, inviting reflection on togetherness, spirituality, and shared identity.

item.title: Sarafina Naisula
item.description: Sarafina Naisula (b. 1999) is a contemporary artist of Tanzanian and Dutch heritage. Educated at the University of Arts, London, her work has been exhibited in the Netherlands and South Africa. Naisula explores human identity, particularly the female experience within the African diaspora, using art to challenge preconceptions and spark dialogue. Her current work addresses sexual abuse and the erosion of individual identity, employing silhouettes and layered mediums to highlight the narratives behind statistics and foster awareness, compassion, and social change.

item.title: Simone Verfaille
item.description: Simone Verfaille (b. 1995, Cape Town) is a contemporary artist whose work reflects life’s layers and experiences. She earned a BA(Hons) Fine Art from Stellenbosch University in 2018 and returned to art in 2023 with renewed focus. Her practice uses layered paint to capture memory, time, and personal expression, creating immersive compositions of colour, form, and texture.

item.title: Tayhe Munsamy
item.description: Tayhe Munsamy (b. Johannesburg, South Africa) is a visual artist whose work explores identity, mythology, and folklore through painting, video, performance, and digital media. A Goldsmiths University of London graduate (BA Fine Art and History of Art, First-Class Honours, 2020), Tayhe’s practice reflects her mixed-race heritage and draws from South Africa’s Coloured and Indian communities. Her art blends historical archives with fictional narratives to explore creation, displacement, transformation, and fantasy. Selected for the 2021 RMB Talent Unlocked mentoring program and group exhibition at Everard Read CIRCA Gallery, Tayhe continues to exhibit her work locally and internationally. She is currently based in Johannesburg.

item.title: Davina de Beer
item.description: Davina de Beer (b.1982) is a South African visual artist based in Seville, Spain. She earned her Master’s in Fine Art in 2008 and spent over a decade in Oman, where she taught Art & Design and exhibited widely, including two solo shows in Dubai and Muscat. Since relocating to Spain in 2022, she has been a finalist in the ARTE APARTE contemporary art competition, exhibited at Galeria Zunino, and co-founded the Non-Site Art Collective, debuting their collaboration at the Turbine Art Fair in Johannesburg (2023).

item.title: Flood House
item.description: Flood House is a creative screen-printing studio. Our focus lies in creative collaboration: working with visual artists, illustrators and designers to create limited edition art prints. Our vision is to promote creative collaboration within the arts by supporting artists and sharing our passion for traditional printmaking. We produce fine art silkscreen prints for clients, both locally and internationally. Check our projects here to see Flood House’s production work. Flood House also co-publishes prints. We join hands with artists to produce limited edition silkscreen prints. View a list of our published works in our shop. Flood House studios are located in Victoria Yards, Johannesburg and is run by artist and printmaker Alexandré Vosloo.

item.title: GxL - L’MAD Collection x Guillotine
item.description: GxL Presents: A Capsule Collection for Giants Introducing an exclusive capsule collection by GxL—the collaboration between L’MAD Collection and Guillotine by Lisa Jaffe.
