This limited range is designed in celebration of artist Cinthia Sifa Mulanga’s long-awaited solo exhibition, Giants. Drawing inspiration from Mulanga's powerful new work, the collection channels the artist's exploration of Black womanhood, inner conflict, and sanctuary. Each piece is crafted from 100% silk and made in South Africa, reflecting the strength and spirit of Mulanga’s art. Pre-Order Information: - This collection is available for pre-order with an expected 7-week delivery time. - Available online at latitudes.online and guillotinebylisajaffe.com.

item.title: Dayna-Gay Tate
item.description: Dayna-Gay Tate (b.1994, Zimbabwe/South Africa) is a Cape Town-based artist and visual storyteller working across painting, design, photography, and poetry. A Stellenbosch University graduate (BA Visual Communication Design, Cum Laude, 2017), her practice explores colour, form, and playful abstraction rooted in faith, memory, and storytelling. Through recurring themes of nature, home, light, and time, Tate invites viewers to pause, embrace joy, and reconnect with stillness.

item.title: Andrew Kayser
item.description: Andrew Kayser (b. 1975, East London, South Africa) is a Johannesburg-based painter whose work explores suburbia as both a lived habitat and a psychological space. Working primarily in oil, he examines ambiguity, contradiction, and fleeting meaning, creating poignant and melancholic reflections on inner and outer realities. A graduate of the Royal Academy of Art, The Hague (2001), Kayser returned to South Africa in 2005 and resumed his practice after overcoming addiction in 2014. He has since held five solo exhibitions, including Fragments of Longer Stories (Graham Contemporary, 2023), and participated in major fairs such as 1-54 (London), AKAA (Paris), and Investec Cape Town Art Fair. His work is held in both local and international collections.

16/16, together with the Friends of 16 network, forms an evolving constellation of creators—artists, facilitators, thinkers, and artisans—who coalesce around a shared commitment: building trust, infrastructure, and possibility within Lagos. At our core, 16/16 is both a physical and conceptual aggregator—a site and a catalyst—where ideas, practices, and relationships are free to germinate across disciplines. Since our inception, we have invited members of our carefully curated creative ecosystem (our 'Friends of 16') to activate 16/16 as a centre for mutual learning and collaboration. Through co‐programming, workshops, open studios, residencies and idea prototyping, we've transformed the space into a prototype of shelter: simultaneously a safe harbour as well as a creative vantage point, continuously orienting our ever-growing community toward the untold potential of our urban futures.)

item.title: Denzil's & Jo Art Gallery
item.description: Denzil's and Jo is a contemporary art gallery dedicated to exploring the vibrant and complex world of art from Africa. Our core mission is to challenge the monolithic categorization of 'African art' by showcasing the continent's immense diversity of cultures, histories, and artistic expressions. Through a program of thought-provoking exhibitions, we address important global issues and work to dismantle preconceived notions, promoting a deeper and more nuanced understanding of the continent. The gallery is a nurturing and supportive platform for talented African artists, providing a space for them to share their unique stories, concepts, and journeys. We are committed to fostering their creative growth and amplifying their voices in the ongoing global dialogue about Africa. We invite you to immerse yourself in the captivating perspectives and connect with the artistic excellence that defines contemporary art from Africa.

item.title: W17 Gallery
item.description: W17 Gallery, part of Workshop17, reimagines the conventional gallery by merging art with everyday spaces. The gallery activates creativity and dialogue, making art accessible, affordable, and engaging for both artists and collectors. Supporting local and international talent, W17 hosts exhibitions, artist talks, walkabouts, and workshops, while collaborating with galleries, studios, and print workshops. Its services include curation, consultations, and art investment, catering to first-time buyers and seasoned collectors alike.

item.title: David Madlabane
item.description: David Madlabane (David Blakc) is a Johannesburg-based visual artist working across drawing, painting, digital art, music, and printmaking techniques such as linocut, silkscreen, and etching. He has assisted at Artist Proof Studio and William Kentridge’s studio, gaining extensive technical experience. Madlabane won first prize in a Cartier collaboration at the FNB Joburg Art Fair, received the People’s Choice Award at the Strauss & Co competition, and was a finalist for the Blessing Ngobeni Art Prize. He continues to build his practice with the ambition of establishing himself internationally.

item.title: Regina Bardavid
item.description: Regina Bardavid is a Johannesburg-based artist whose work explores abstract expressionism through vibrant, non-figurative forms. Inspired by meditation, intuition, and everyday patterns—like coffee remnants—her paintings are spontaneous explorations that evoke emotion and imagination.

item.title: Mbali Shabane
item.description: Mbalenhle Shabane (b. 1990, Durban) is a South African artist and emerging curator whose work explores the female journey through themes of identity, spirituality, trauma, and healing. A Fine Arts graduate from Durban University of Technology, she launched Change Room (2019), a collaborative project fostering dialogue among womxn. Her work was recently featured in Durban: A Curatorial Journey (2024) at The Pencil Club.

item.title: Wunika Mukan Gallery
item.description: Wunika Mukan Gallery, formerly Pacers, is a contemporary art gallery in Lagos, Nigeria, founded in 2020 by Wunika Mukan. The gallery champions emerging artists from Nigeria, Sub-Saharan Africa, and the diaspora, providing a platform for local and international exposure and engagement with the wider art market. Committed to innovation and artistic excellence, Wunika Mukan Gallery supports experimentation with new ideas, techniques, and mediums, establishing itself as a key force in Nigeria’s contemporary art scene.

item.title: BODE
item.description: Bode is a contemporary gallery with spaces in Berlin and Havana, dedicated to collaborating with a diverse and international group of artists. The gallery's program focuses on practices that explore and challenge traditional notions of representation. Through concept, medium, and aesthetics, the artists we work with push the boundaries of contemporary art across a wide range of disciplines. In addition to its exhibition schedule, Bode is committed to fostering creative dialogue through an artist-in-residence program and collaborations with curators, institutions, and other partners worldwide.

item.title: Afriart Gallery
item.description: Founded in Kampala in 2002, Afriart Gallery (AAG) has grown into a leading international voice for contemporary art from the African continent. We are dedicated to showcasing original forms of expression and creating a dynamic environment where collectors can engage with powerful artistic ideas and discussions. Our gallery was established by artist Daudi Karungi, whose firsthand experience informs our artist-centric mission. We are deeply committed to building a supportive and equitable community, actively fostering our artists' careers through dedicated mentorship, strategic visibility, and diligent archiving of their work. This commitment has successfully launched our artists onto the world stage. Works by AAG artists are consistently featured in major museums, biennales, and the world's most prestigious art fairs, including Art Basel Miami Beach, EXPO Chicago, Art Paris, 1:54 Contemporary African Art Fair, and FNB Art Joburg, among many others.

item.title: THIS IS NOT A WHITE CUBE
item.description: THIS IS NOT A WHITE CUBE is a contemporary art gallery based in Luanda and Lisbon, representing emerging and established artists from Africa, its diaspora, and the Global South. The gallery fosters intercultural dialogue through both in-gallery and off-site exhibitions, highlighting themes like identity, memory, and social change. Founded by Sónia Ribeiro and Graça Rodrigues, it also runs O CUBO, a non-profit supporting residencies, research, and international collaborations. The gallery participates in exhibitions worldwide, promoting experimentation and global engagement.

item.title: Affinity Gallery
item.description: Based in Lagos, Nigeria, Affinity Art Gallery is a contemporary art space founded in 2020 with a mission to champion the next generation of artists from Africa and its diaspora. We are deeply committed to providing a platform where emerging talent can explore creative ideas across all mediums, without boundaries. Through a dynamic program of curated exhibitions, participation in international art fairs, and engaging educational initiatives, we offer collectors, museums, and foundations unique access to an incredible selection of artists. Our ultimate purpose is to accelerate our artists' careers on the global stage, sharing the rich cultural heritage of Africa and inspiring future generations.

item.title: Adeyosola Adeniran
item.description: Adeyosola Adeniran, an artist and curator based in Lagos, Nigeria, currently serves as Curatorial Assistant at the African Artists' Foundation and LagosPhoto Festival. Her curatorial practice is based on close collaboration with artists to realise and/or present their best work.

item.title: Baoagi Keitshokile
item.description: Baoagi One Keitshokile is a multidisciplinary artist from Serowe, Botswana. Immersed in cultural and performing arts from a young age, he later studied art and design, cultivating a practice that spans visual art, poetry, music, and curation. A member of the Art of the Poets collective since 2007, he has showcased work across Botswana, South Africa, and Zimbabwe. Based at Khama III Memorial Museum, where he manages a studio and assists with exhibitions, Baoagi also adjudicates national arts competitions. His practice, rooted in versatility, centres on enlightenment as empowerment, using art to inspire positivity and confront social challenges.

item.title: Bayron Van Wyk
item.description: Bayron Van Wyk is a writer, researcher, and cultural worker. He holds a BA (Hons) from the University of Namibia and an MA in Anthropology from the University of the Western Cape. Since 2022, he has worked with the Museums Association of Namibia, engaging with Namibian collections and their colonial histories. His work focuses on restitution, provenance research, and artistic engagement with cultural objects to promote ethical practices in heritage and museum spaces.

item.title: Giancarlo LaGuerta
item.description: Giancarlo Diablo LaGuerta is a self-taught multidisciplinary artist and curator based in Gaborone, Botswana. His work spans painting, drawing, collage, photography, video, and music, exploring politics, masculinity, culture, and heritage. Giancarlo often creates large-scale, experimental pieces that blur representation and abstraction, amplifying personal and collective experiences of emotion, grief, and societal issues.

item.title: Kamogelo Sebopa
item.description: Kamogelo Sebopa is a Johannesburg based emerging artist and curator. Sebopa recently obtained her degree in BA Fine Art program at the University of the Witwatersrand. Sebopa is currently interested in drawing and printmaking and furthering her curatorial practice. She was recently shortlisted and won the CCAC student competition for printmaking.

item.title: Kukua Kweku-Badu
item.description: Kukua Kweku-Badu is an independent curator and poet exploring decolonial and queer alternate realities within global contemporary art. Their work centers on amplifying the narratives of queer/trans-Indigenous individuals from the Global South and diaspora, while reimagining ways of presenting and engaging with art. Kukua holds a BA in Communications Studies from the Ghana Institute of Journalism and has experience in media, marketing, and artist support.

item.title: Ng'onga Silupya
item.description: Ng’onga Silupya (b. 1996, Lusaka, Zambia) is a cultural practitioner, curator, and arts administrator. Her work explores the intersections of cultural heritage, contemporary art, and social, environmental, and political issues. She currently serves as Administrator and Assistant Curator at the Lusaka Contemporary Art Centre and has extensive experience with the Zambia National Visual Arts Council and Lechwe Trust Art Gallery.

item.title: Onyinye Alheri
item.description: Onyịnye Alheri is a multidisciplinary artist and curator born in Lagos, Nigeria and living in southern Africa. At the core of Ọ’s practice is an exploration into the depths of consciousness and existence. Alheri is a member of Aguas Migrantes, a collective composed of interdisciplinary artists across continents.

item.title: Raelee Seymour-Brown
item.description: Raelee Seymour-Brown is a Johannesburg-based multimedia artist, designer, and curator. Her work explores the unseen within pop culture, transforming the mundane into thought-provoking experiences across digital illustration, writing, ceramics, fashion, and design. Through diverse mediums, she investigates the complexities of contemporary life with irreverence and curiosity.

item.title: Chloë Shain
item.description: Chloë Shain (b. 1993, Johannesburg) is a multidisciplinary artist and anthropologist. She holds an Honours in Fine Art from Wits University and a PhD in Anthropology from the University of Cape Town. Shain works across painting, digital collage, video animation, and installation, exploring human relationships with mobile devices through touchscreen gestures. Her recent exhibitions include Nirox Sculpture Park, NewWork22 at Wits Art Museum, and the Turbine Art Fair, where she was selected for the 2023 Unearthed mentorship programme.

item.title: Chuma Adam
item.description: Chuma Adam (b. 2001) is a Johannesburg-based multidisciplinary artist working across painting, printmaking, textiles, sculpture, and drawing. Influenced by Édouard Glissant’s Poetics of Relation, her practice engages themes of visibility, Blackness, and self-actualization through abstraction, texture, and mark-making. Mixing earth from her mother’s home into her work, Adam creates immersive pieces that explore the intersections of Blackness, womanhood, and African artistic lineage. She holds an Honours degree in Fine Arts from Wits University (2024) and was shortlisted for the WITS Young Artist Award in 2022 and 2023.

item.title: Kutti Collective
item.description: Kutti Collective is a group of six young South African artists of South Asian ancestry who challenge social norms while redefining identity and representation. Reclaiming the word Kutti—which can mean both “bitch” and “darling” across South Asian languages—they subvert its patriarchal weight to assert power and agency. Their work reflects on ancestry, lived experiences, and traumas, complicating ideas of what it means to be South Asian and ‘Indian’ today.

item.title: Marie-Lorraine Kalassa
item.description: Marie-Lorraine Kalassa is a South African artist of Congolese descent whose work explores identity, ancestry, and notions of home. Using personal archives, reflexive writing, and diverse media, she investigates how memory, place, and culture shape selfhood and belonging. Kalassa holds a Fine Arts degree from Michaelis School of Fine Arts and an Honours in Landscape Architecture from the University of Cape Town. She is a member of The Photographic Collective (TPC) and has exhibited in shows including JIVE Exhibition (2023), We Are Culture (2022), and 1-54 Contemporary African Art Fair (London, 2021).

item.title: Nathaniel Sheppard III
item.description: Nathaniel Sheppard III (b. 1989) is a Johannesburg-based printmaker, painter, and collage artist. Trained at WITS and David Krut Projects, his practice combines printmaking, painting, and found imagery to explore culture, politics, and identity. In 2016, he co-founded Danger Gevaar Ingozi Studio, a collective rooted in independent publishing and printmaking’s social value.

item.title: Sahlah Davids
item.description: Sahlah Davids (b. 1998, Cape Town) is a mixed media artist working with textiles and beadwork. A graduate of UCT (2020), her practice explores the intertwined histories of religion, politics, and heritage within the Cape Muslim community. Drawing on the skills of her seamstress grandmother and tailor grandfather, Davids transforms traditional craft into a quiet act of protest and a visual archive of resilience, spirituality, and generational struggle.

item.title: Tamary Kudita
item.description: Tamary Kudita is a multi-award-winning Zimbabwean fine art photographer, scholar, and visual artist exploring African identity, cultural duality, and transgenerational memory. A Michaelis School of Fine Art graduate (BFA, 2017), she gained international recognition as the first African to win the 2021 Open Photographer of the Year at the Sony World Photography Awards for her series African Victorian. Kudita’s work has been exhibited globally, including Art Basel Miami, Sharjah Xposure, Investec Cape Town Art Fair, and Photo Vogue Festival Milan. Her accolades include the J.M.D Manyika Fellowship (Harvard, 2023), See Me Art Takes Runner Up (2021), and honorable mentions from the International Photography Awards. Her art is held in prestigious collections, including the Fitchburg Art Museum (USA) and The Betsy Gallery (Florida), and has been featured in international media such as BBC, CNN, Forbes, and Vogue Italia.

item.title: Salon Kewpie
item.description: Salon Kewpie: The Legacy Project is an interdisciplinary platform providing queer and disadvantaged youth with creative access to the themes embodied in the Kewpie Collection. The initiative bridges contemporary ballroom culture with a rich historical photographic archive, centred on the life of Kewpie Fritz (1941–2012) — a celebrated hairdresser, performer, and fearless queer icon of apartheid-era District Six. Through workshops led by experts in activism, mental health, ballroom culture, and drag artistry, the programme nurtures personal and artistic growth while reclaiming histories of resilience, freedom, and belonging. The culmination of this journey is the Salon Kewpie: The Legacy Ball — a vibrant celebration uniting youth, queer and trans elders, and the District Six community in honour of Kewpie’s enduring spirit. Bringing Kewpie’s legacy home to District Six.

item.title: Andrea Burgener
item.description: Andrea Burgener (MAFA, Wits) is a Johannesburg-based artist, chef and food writer whose practice merges artmaking with research into the politics of food. Working with diverse media—from paint and animation to food packaging and cake—she explores themes of land, power, consumption, and culpability with wit and sharp critique. Recurring motifs like chef toques, rats, and phosphorescent objects trace connections between agriculture, warfare, and globalised food systems, questioning the ethics of consumption and the invisibility of labour in industrial production.

item.title: Occupying The Gallery
item.description: Occupying the Gallery is a visual arts project, mentorship program, mobile studio, and artist residency founded in July 2023 by Mary Sibande and Lawrence Lemaoana. It collaborates with emerging artists—called “Occupants”—to produce experimental and immersive exhibitions, transforming gallery spaces into interactive experiences. The initiative spans diverse media, fostering dialogue around identity, space, and culture while bridging access to industry, professional growth, and opportunities for young artists.

item.title: Candice Berman Gallery
item.description: Since 2013, Candice Berman Gallery has been a premier destination in Johannesburg for fine art collectors. Guided by a deep curiosity for the cultural and personal narratives behind art, the gallery represents a diverse collection of media with a primary focus on the Expressionist Movement. The gallery is founded on a commitment to supporting the development of its artists, creating novel opportunities for their work to be shared both locally and internationally. We consider it our privilege to connect collectors with exceptional raw talent and unique, compelling pieces. Beyond its exhibition program, Candice Berman Gallery offers a complete suite of services. Our expert consultants collaborate with clients to build unique collections, while our highly trained team provides professional installation. We also offer custom, museum-quality framing as a certified Guild-Commended Framer, ensuring the highest standard of care for your artworks. We invite you to visit our regularly hosted exhibitions to discover the artists shaping the contemporary art landscape.

item.title: Yenwa Gallery
item.description: Yenwa Gallery, founded in 2021 by curator and designer Ugonna Ibe, is a contemporary gallery in Lagos, Nigeria, representing emerging and mid-career artists across Africa and its diaspora. With a focus on women in photography and new media, the gallery showcases work exploring identity, spirituality, culture, and socio-economic themes. Since opening in April 2023, Yenwa Gallery has emphasized community, innovation, and dialogue, supporting artists through exhibitions, collaborations, educational initiatives, and participation in international art fairs.

item.title: Untitled Art
item.description: Untitled creates accessible and inclusive spaces for people to discover, explore, and buy art. Since launching in 2020, the platform has engaged audiences through studio visits, digital content, and participation in fairs like Investec Cape Town Art Fair (ALT) and FNB Art Joburg (LAB). Focusing on authentic connections, Untitled works with both emerging and established South African artists to foster meaningful engagement between artists, collectors, and art lovers.

item.title: Nelson Makamo Studio
item.description: Nelson Makamo is a Johannesburg-based artist from Limpopo, South Africa, celebrated for his compelling portraits of African children that capture resilience, beauty, and emotion. Working across charcoal, acrylic, print, and watercolor, his storytelling emphasizes spontaneity and expressive mark-making. Trained at Artist Proof Studios, Makamo draws influence from Dumile Feni, Picasso, and Van Gogh. His work has been exhibited internationally—in South Africa, the USA, France, Italy, the Netherlands, England, and Scotland—and is included in prestigious collections worldwide. Makamo has also gained mainstream recognition, appearing on The Daily Show with Trevor Noah and on the cover of Time magazine, while mentoring young African artists and reshaping global perceptions of African childhood.

item.title: Keabetse Maake
item.description: Keabetse Maake is a multidisciplinary artist from Tembisa, Gauteng. Working across textile art, printmaking, photography, design, and performance, she is best known for her vibrant yarn paintings that weave stories of Black joy, fantasy, and identity. Rooted in her experiences and cultural background, Maake’s work celebrates the exuberance of youth while exploring the complexities of African heritage and belonging.

item.title: Lemkus Gallery
item.description: Lemkus Gallery, located in the Exchange Building on St George’s Mall, was founded in 2024 to host and support the Residency28 programme — an initiative providing emerging local artists with studio space, funding, and professional support to develop sustainable creative practices. Backed by Lemkus and PayJustNow, the residency offers five weeks of studio access, a stipend for materials and living expenses, mentorship, and culminates in a solo exhibition at the gallery. Beyond the residency, Lemkus Gallery functions as a dynamic project space, hosting group shows and experimental exhibitions to foster collaboration and community within Cape Town’s arts scene.

item.title: Amasaka Gallery
item.description: Amasaka Gallery is a dynamic contemporary art space in Masaka, Uganda, established in 2020 by artist Collin Sekajugo. The gallery is dedicated to showcasing and nurturing the region's most promising emerging artistic talent. Born from Sekajugo's acclaimed Weaver Bird Residency program, Amasaka Gallery's founding mission is to provide mentorship, support, and a platform for experimentation. It fosters a creative environment where local and regional artists are encouraged to push the boundaries of their practice, from painting and photography to installation. With a satellite space in Kampala and a network of international collaborations, Amasaka is actively redefining the regional art scene and inviting the global art world to look beyond its traditional centres. Through its ambitious program of exhibitions, art fair participation, and collaborative projects, the gallery has quickly established itself as a vital contributor to both local and international art communities.

item.title: Isabella Maake
item.description: Isabella Maake is a South African contemporary visual artist who, living with profound hearing loss, uses art to explore identity, duality, and vulnerability through portraiture and figurative work. A multidisciplinary practitioner, she works in painting, photography, sculpture, and interactive sound. Isabella has exhibited at the 1-54 Contemporary African Art Fair (London) and in Polokwane, South Africa. In 2023, she received a Chevening Scholarship and is pursuing a master’s in Fine Art at Oxford.

item.title: Yaknoabasi Jessicah Ene
item.description: Yakno-Abasi Ene is a Lagos-based abstract realism artist whose work explores sisterhood, women’s empowerment, and the divine feminine. Inspired by the strong women in her family, she celebrates unity, resilience, and grace through her art, using diverse mediums to reflect her personal experiences and evolving imagination. Her practice seeks to educate, heal, and inspire, highlighting the strength and beauty of women in contemporary society.

item.title: Lee-Ann Olwage
item.description: Lee-Ann Olwage is a South African visual storyteller whose collaborative photography explores themes of gender and identity. With a background in film directing and set design, she creates affirming, narrative-driven imagery that celebrates her subjects’ agency. Her acclaimed project The Right To Play highlights the barriers girls face in accessing education while imagining empowering, playful futures where they thrive. Olwage’s work has appeared in National Geographic, Vogue, The Guardian, and Foam Magazine. She is a multi-award-winning artist, with honours including the World Press Photo Award (2020, 2023, 2024) and the Sony World Photography Award (2023).

item.title: Marie Aimée Fattouche
item.description: Marie Aimée Fattouche (b. 1991, lives and works in Seine-Saint-Denis, France) is a multidisciplinary artist whose work explores the mechanics of mind, body, and environment. Drawing from her Egyptian heritage, she examines power structures, femininity, and collective belief systems through fluid, ever-evolving compositions that blur the boundaries between rupture and repair. A graduate of Chelsea College of Arts, London (MA Fine Art, 2016), Fattouche has received several accolades, including the Mercers’ Arts Award and the Red Mansion Art Prize. Her work has been exhibited internationally at venues such as the Museum of Modern and Contemporary Art (MAMC+), Standpoint Gallery, and Galerie du Haut-Pavé, where she presented her solo show NOUS INFINIR MON AMOUR in 2024.

item.title: Silindokuhle Shandu
item.description: Silindokuhle Shandu (b. 1998, Johannesburg) is a multidisciplinary artist whose work explores womanhood, identity, and the contrasts between urban, suburban, and rural South Africa. Drawing on her upbringing in Empangeni and eMalahleni, she uses color, texture, and composition to reflect on belonging, otherness, and personal journey. She holds a diploma in Fashion Design and Technology from Tshwane University of Technology.

item.title: Southern Guild
item.description: Southern Guild, founded in 2008 by Trevyn and Julian McGowan, represents contemporary African artists from the continent and diaspora, with locations in Cape Town and Los Angeles. The gallery supports artists exploring culture, spirituality, identity, ancestral knowledge, and ecology through collaborative projects, exhibitions, and its GUILD Residency programme. Southern Guild fosters emerging talent via education, mentorship, and interdisciplinary initiatives, while participating in international fairs and biennales. Its artists’ works are held in major collections, including the Metropolitan Museum of Art, LACMA, Art Institute of Chicago, Pérez Art Museum, and Vitra Museum, and have exhibited at institutions such as Centre Pompidou, Brooklyn Museum, Seoul Museum of Art, and Cooper Hewitt Smithsonian Design Museum.

item.title: Queens Brussels
item.description: Queens Brussels is a multidisciplinary art space housed in a historic mansion, showcasing painting, photography, sculpture, video, performance, and digital art. The gallery supports artist residencies, providing visibility and flexible spaces for creative development. Its intimate Louis XVI-style rooms also host chamber concerts, jazz performances, and jam sessions, creating a vibrant cultural hub.

item.title: Sarah Jayne Fell
item.description: Sarah Jayne Fell (b. 1986, Cape Town) is a painter whose work explores personal myth through expressionism and process art, with a focus on colour and light. Drawing on dreams, journaling, and freestyle painting, her practice is autobiographical and cathartic, blending painting, digital collage, and poetry. Fell began creating art in her mother’s ceramic studio in KwaZulu-Natal and later studied creative writing, media, philosophy, and literature. She has exhibited at the KZNSA, ANON. Pop Up, and Zeitz MOCAA, and currently works from her studio in Kommetjie, Cape Town.

item.title: Yasmine Amal
item.description: Yasmine Amal is a self-taught German-Moroccan artist and political scientist. Her work explores ancestral connection, intersectional feminism, and the meaning of Indigeneity. Drawing inspiration from the ocean and Amazigh symbolism, she creates paintings that reflect harmony, heritage, and collective responsibility. Currently an art fellow at laba Berlin and Künstlerhaus Bethanien, she uses art to foster cross-cultural dialogue and shared values.

item.title: Mpumi Mayisa
item.description: Mpumi Mayisa is a Johannesburg-based curator, cultural worker, and art writer focused on archives and memory. Her work explores personal and collective histories, creating dialogues between past and present through exhibitions such as Bathini Abafazi? and A Crescendo of DayDreams. Mpumi is also the founder of Among The Lilies, a creative platform supporting artistic practice and community engagement.

item.title: Hanien Conradie
item.description: Hanien Conradie is a South African earth artist whose work combines painting, performance, and natural pigments to explore human-nature relationships. She holds an MFA from Michaelis School of Fine Art, UCT, and draws inspiration from landscapes across Southern Africa and Botswana. Her work, including landscape paintings and organic installations, has been exhibited locally and internationally, with solo shows such as Raaswater (2019) and Spoorloos (2021), and group exhibitions including Earth Power! (2022, Brussels) and 1-54 London. Conradie’s practice encourages reflection on humanity’s connection to nature.

item.title: Blessing Blaai
item.description: Blessing N Blaai (b. 1994, Johannesburg) is an artist whose practice spans painting, drawing, printmaking, and mural art. Rooted in the suburban landscape of Troyeville, his work reflects a deep engagement with community and urban space. A graduate of Artist Proof Studio, where he specialised in printmaking, Blaai has developed a versatile practice that includes watercolour, ink, and mixed media. As a muralist, he has contributed to public and private commissions, including city-commissioned projects that transform urban environments. His work has been featured in group exhibitions such as African Mobilities: This Is Not a Refugee Camp. Dedicated to art as a tool for connection, Blaai has also facilitated community arts programs with the Market Foundation at Windybrow Theatre, creating creative outlets for children in Hillbrow and beyond.

item.title: Lerato Motaung
item.description: Lerato Motaung (b. 1991, Germiston) is a Johannesburg-based multidisciplinary artist whose practice explores memory, identity, and collective narratives. Through expressive color and layered compositions, Motaung reflects on the emotional weight of remembrance, transformation, and resilience. He holds a National Diploma in Fine Art from Tshwane University of Technology and was a finalist in the 2021 Sasol New Signatures Awards. His international recognition includes the Our Africa, Our Future residency in Senegal (2022) and exhibitions at Christie's Paris, Haart Gallery London, THK Gallery Cologne, and the Pretoria Art Museum. Motaung’s work forms part of major collections including Foundation H (Paris and Madagascar) and Africa First.

item.title: Simon Venter
item.description: Simon Venter is a multidisciplinary artist whose practice bridges traditional fine arts and emerging technologies. With a foundation in classical oil painting, he incorporates AI to explore creativity, human agency, and the impact of technology on artistic expression. Drawing from global traditions and South African visual storytelling, Venter’s work examines existential themes, archetypes, and the tension between history and innovation. He has exhibited locally and internationally and holds a Master’s in Creative Media and Production.

item.title: Lugra Ilunga
item.description: Lugra Israel Ilunga (b.1995, Lubumbashi, DRC) is a Johannesburg-based mixed-media artist exploring masculinity in contemporary society. Using ink, charcoal, collage, and oil pastels, he examines societal pressures on men through cityscapes, landmarks, and symbolic objects. Ilunga has exhibited locally and integrates human rights themes into his work alongside his law degree from the University of Johannesburg.

item.title: Karin Preller
item.description: Karin Preller is a Johannesburg-based artist whose work transforms everyday snapshots into haunting reflections on memory and time. A former lawyer with a PhD in Art and Design from the University of Johannesburg, her paintings explore the tension between remembrance and loss. Preller has exhibited widely, with Beyond Memory (2022) earning the KKNK KANNA Award and a KykNET Fiësta nomination. Her work is held in major South African collections, including the Johannesburg Art Gallery and ABSA.

item.title: Ada-Ruth Kellow
item.description: Ada-Ruth Kellow (b. 1957, Germany) is a Johannesburg-based figurative painter. Working in the tradition of social critique, her art confronts uncomfortable truths through realistic rendering, rich symbolism, and ornamental detail. Kellow holds a BA Honours in Fine Arts (with distinction) from Wits University and was a 2024 finalist for the prestigious Rust-en-Vrede Portrait Award. Her work invites viewers to uncover complex narratives that balance confrontation with moments of dark humour and consolation.

item.title: Sam Kentridge
item.description: Sam Kentridge (b. 1992, Johannesburg) is an artist whose work revolves around language, fragmented text, and collage, exploring how meaning is constructed and disrupted. A former high school English and History teacher, Sam draws on his fascination with narrative, humor, and everyday absurdities. His work has been featured in group exhibitions at The Gallery (Johannesburg), Turbine Art Fair (2022), and Latitudes Art Fair (2023).

item.title: KulnZu
item.description: kulnZu (b. 1998) is a Mozambican artist and scholar based in Nairobi, Kenya. Working across photography, collage, and writing, their practice explores queerness and tender representations of queer intimacy and masculinities. They hold a B.A. in Africana Studies from Pomona College and are pursuing an MSc in African Studies at the University of Oxford. Their research and art engage with queer urban cultural production, mobility, and the imagining of ‘afroqueer futurity’—envisioning queer lives, bodies, and belonging through creative practice.

item.title: Banana Club
item.description: BANANA CLUB is an interdisciplinary artistic collective founded in 2019 to foster critical discourse at the intersection of contemporary art, design, film, and human rights. Our core mission is to amplify marginalized voices and build sustainable career opportunities for emerging artists. Through a dynamic program of art residencies, community dialogues, and art education initiatives, we serve as a vital platform for cultural exchange and innovation. Based in Botswana, we are dedicated to championing the nation's burgeoning contemporary arts ecosystem while strategically positioning its artists and thinkers within broader African and global conversations.

item.title: TBP Artist Collective
item.description: TBP Artist Collective (formerly The Botswana Pavilion) is a Botswana-based artist platform founded in 2019, comprising Kim Karabo Makin, LegakwanaLeo Makgekgenene, Rrangwane, Thebe Phetogo, and Thero Makepe. The collective champions Botswana’s creative development and archives its artistic practices, addressing under-representation locally and internationally. Drawing inspiration from national pavilions at global events, TBP bridges fine art, visual art, and traditional crafts. Its projects include exhibitions like No Return (Gallery MOMO, 2019), Subjective Nationhood (Botswana National Art Gallery, 2019), the virtual Collective Ties (2020), and Maš(w)i a Ditoro (tsa Rona) (Frankfurt, 2022). TBP also produced the video Kgolokwe: Separated Intersections, screened internationally in Basel, New York, Cape Town, São Paulo, and Berlin.

item.title: The Space Botswana
item.description: Located in the heart of Maun, The Space Botswana is a dynamic art gallery and creative hub, housed in a repurposed shipping container—symbolizing resilience and artistic innovation. Established in 2019, it serves as a platform for local and international artists, fostering collaboration and cultural exchange. Beyond exhibitions, it offers a makers-space for sculptors and designers, as well as immersive art retreats that blend creativity with the natural beauty of the Okavango Delta. A true sanctuary for artists and art enthusiasts alike, The Space Botswana is redefining the creative landscape of Southern Africa.

item.title: Kavula Art Studio
item.description: Kavula Art Studio is a professional l art studio which Bonolo Kavula intends to use as a space for young artists to be mentored under. It can also be described as school of thought or a workshop for new artistic ideas to emerge.

item.title: Art Residency Centre
item.description: The Art Residency Centre (ARC) is an artist-led initiative in Gaborone, Botswana, dedicated to providing space, support, and new platforms for contemporary creatives. At its core, ARC offers a residency program that provides selected artists with time, space, mentorship, and resources for a period of one to three months. The program is designed to actively contribute to the development of the artist's creative practice. Located at the Gaborone Sports & Social Club, ARC's studio and reference library, 'The ARChive,' serves as a hub for both the resident artist and the wider community. It is open to the public on Saturdays, offering opportunities for dialogue and feedback. Beyond the residency, ARC fosters a vibrant cultural ecosystem through regular film screenings, reading groups, zine workshops, exhibitions, and talks. Through a strong network of local collaborators, ARC provides invaluable networking opportunities and diverse platforms for creatives to develop, dialogue, and display their work.

item.title: DESIRE MAREA
item.description: Desire Marea (Duma Buyani) (b. 1991, Scottburgh, KwaZulu-Natal) is a South African artist based in Amandawe. Orphaned at six, they were raised by a supportive extended family and later discovered their lineage to Menzi Mcunu, a celebrated Durban artist and community activist. Marea studied at the National School of the Arts and earned a BA in Visual Communication from Vega School. Deeply inspired by Black culture, history, and family, their work draws on influences from artists such as Zanele Muholi, Athi-Patra Ruga, Sabelo Mlangeni, and Luvuyo Nyawose.

item.title: Locus
item.description: Locus is a contemporary art platform founded by Isa Schwartz Gesseau, dedicated to supporting artists and expanding their reach. Drawing on over twenty years of experience across art, design, and education, Isa created Locus to nurture artistic careers through curated exhibitions and participation in local and international art fairs.

item.title: Asisebenze Art Atelier
item.description: Asisebenze Art Atelier (AAA) is a dynamic artistic hub in the heart of Johannesburg, uniquely combining an artist residency, studio spaces, and a dealership within a single ecosystem. Located in the historic Blue Plaque Heritage Building at 28 Plein Street, AAA is dedicated to nurturing and showcasing both emerging and established African creative talent. Spanning six floors, the atelier provides artists with housing, studio space, and professional mentorship, empowering them to build sustainable careers while pursuing creative freedom. The art created within Asisebenze is a direct reflection of Johannesburg's vibrant inner-city energy, with each piece telling a story of contemporary African life, culture, and identity. As a key player in the local art scene, AAA offers a direct gateway to the soul of Johannesburg's contemporary art, fostering a space where talent flourishes and careers are built

item.title: BNAP Foundation
item.description: BNAP Foundation is a non-profit organisation dedicated to supporting emerging artists in South Africa through residencies, professional development, and creative exchange. Its mission is to help artists sustain their careers by offering workshops in business and artistic growth, while fostering international networking and collaboration. The foundation also runs the Blessing Ngobeni Art Prize, which supports outstanding artists under 35 working in painting, sculpture, mixed media, or performance. Recipients receive studio space, a materials budget, a stipend, mentorship, and a funded solo exhibition. BNAP Foundation is proudly sponsored by Art Angels, the Johannesburg Stock Exchange (JSE), and Everard Read Gallery Cape Town.

item.title: Candice Kramer
item.description: Candice Michelle Kramer (b. 1974, Johannesburg) is a South African painter exploring the transience of life against Johannesburg’s enduring cityscape. Working with metal surfaces, rust, and corrosion, her work references people, family photos, and maps to examine memory, time, and urban belonging. Kramer holds a BA in Fine Arts from Wits University and has exhibited at Obert Contemporary, NIROX Projects, Kalashnikovv Gallery, and 1:54 London Art Fair. Her work is in collections including Spier, Nandos, RMB, and FirstRand, and she is a resident artist at The Bag Factory, Johannesburg.

item.title: AMG Projects
item.description: Based in Lagos, Nigeria, AMG Projects is a contemporary art gallery on a mission to empower emerging African artists and curators. The gallery serves as a critical gateway for discovering game-changing talent, providing a vital platform to facilitate broader social access and global opportunities. AMG Projects curates and supports ambitious projects across diverse media, from painting and mixed-media to conceptual installations. The gallery's program is geared towards promoting curiosity and encouraging critical dialogue, with a particular focus on post-colonial and socio-political contexts in Africa. Through its dynamic exhibitions and participation in major art fairs, AMG Projects actively works to connect the continent's artists with the international art world.

item.title: Kevin Collins
item.description: Kevin Collins studied painting at the Michaelis School of Fine Art, UCT, under Stanley Pinker, Helmut Starke, and Cecil Skotnes. After two decades in brand communications, a health setback led him back to art, culminating in his 2003 solo exhibition The Taxonomy of Non-Endangered Species at Gallery Moja. Now working primarily in ceramics, Collins draws inspiration from travel, childhood imagery, and everyday ephemera. His works are held in collections across South Africa and internationally.

item.title: The Spaces Africa
item.description: The Spaces Africa is a dynamic platform dedicated to amplifying the presence and impact of young African galleries in the global art ecosystem. Co-founded by Gallerists Atang L.S. Arnold and Frehiwot Demissie, The Spaces Africa is a network that empowers emerging galleries, artists and art spaces by providing visibility, resources, and collaborative opportunities to help them thrive in an increasingly competitive art market. By connecting young African Galleries to the world, we aim to transform our passions into sustainable success by bridging the gaps and establishing pathways for African Contemporary Art.

item.title: First Light Project
item.description: The First Light Project is an innovative art initiative based in Modimolle, Limpopo, where art, nature, and ophthalmology converge. Hosted within the Hope for the Blind (HFTB) eye hospital, the project integrates an exhibition space into the clinic’s design—offering post-operative patients their first visual encounter with art after cataract surgery. Curated by Johan Stegmann and Lawrence Lemaoana, the project reimagines art’s role in healing by transforming restored sight into a deeply emotional and aesthetic experience. Beyond showcasing contemporary works, it reflects on vision, perception, and renewal. Proceeds from the First Light Project, including a portion of each artwork sold, directly support subsidised eye surgeries for disadvantaged patients—merging creativity with compassion to restore both sight and hope.

item.title: RMB Talent Unlocked
item.description: RMB has an established reputation for identifying, attracting, nurturing, rewarding and celebrating exceptional talent. Liberating diverse talent to do good business for a better world is in our DNA, and we believe that ‘unlocking talent’ is key to our ongoing success. This core, ‘talent-centric’ commitment extends through all our brand partnerships, like our broad investment across the creative economy. Through RMB Talent Unlocked and in partnership with the FirstRand Foundation, we are proud to be part of the vital role that the visual arts play in our society, as both a catalyst for conversation and an archive of time.

item.title: Azola Kingston
item.description: Azola Kingston (b. 1994, Philadelphia; raised in Johannesburg) is a self-taught visual artist whose work is a bold celebration of Blackness. Through vibrant colour and layered composition, she affirms African stories, traditions, and voices as central to the cultural conversation. Her paintings draw beauty from community, shared rituals, and generational wisdom, creating vivid, powerful narratives of pride, presence, and resilience.

item.title: Amy Rusch
item.description: Amy Rusch is a multidisciplinary artist whose practice explores vibrational mark-making through stitched thread in found plastic. Her process—cutting, stitching, heating, layering—transforms discarded materials into reflections on human and elemental time. She has exhibited widely, with recent presentations at Investec Cape Town Art Fair (2025), FNB Art Joburg (2024), and a solo with SMAC Gallery (2022). Her work has also featured at the Norval Foundation, Pretoria Art Museum, Iziko South African National Gallery, and Zeitz MOCAA.

item.title: Chigozie Obi
item.description: Chigozie Obi (b. 1997) is a Nigerian multidisciplinary artist whose practice reflects on human complexity, beauty, culture, women’s narratives, mental health, and healing. Her work draws from personal and collective experiences to foster connection and dialogue. She earned a Visual Arts degree from the University of Lagos in 2017 and has exhibited internationally, including 1-54 Marrakech (2025), Yenwa Gallery, Lagos (2024), AG18 Gallery, Vienna (2024), and Future Fair, New York (2023). Obi won the Access Bank Art X Prize (2021), The Future Awards Prize for Art (2021), and held a residency at Gasworks, London (2022).

item.title: Fetlework Tadesse
item.description: Fetlework Tadesse (Fela), born in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, is a painter and sculptor. She holds a diploma in Fine Arts (sculpture) from Entoto Technical College (2004) and a BA in Painting from Addis Ababa University (2019). Fela has participated in numerous group exhibitions at venues including the Ethiopian National Theatre, Ethiopian National Museum, Red Door Art Gallery, and Addis Fine Art. Her debut solo exhibition was held at Findika Cultural Center in 2023, and she has exhibited internationally, including at the Addis Ababa Modern Art Museum and the Investec Cape Town Art Fair (2024). Her semi-realistic work often features self-portraits reflecting daily life, emotions, and attitudes, inspired by body gestures, fashion, and everyday patterns. Fela explores anatomy, structure, and color to convey personal narratives. She is part of the “Roots and Wings” group exhibition in Stuttgart, Germany (July 2025).

item.title: Chinecherem Peace
item.description: Chinecherem is a Nigerian textile artist whose practice reflects personal emotions and women’s lived realities while bridging tradition and innovation. She graduated as Best Student in Industrial Design (Textile) from IMT Enugu in 2017. Her work has featured in exhibitions such as the 2025 Kuenyehia Prize for Contemporary Art Exhibition, +234 Art Fair, Rele Arts Foundation’s Young Contemporaries (2025), and the 2021 My View From the Other Side exhibition at the Embassy of Spain, Abuja. She won the 2024 Kuenyehia Prize for Contemporary Art, and is a 2024 Fellow of both the Rele Arts Foundation and Kuta Art Residency.

item.title: Aleruchi Kinika
item.description: Aleruchi Kinika (b.1997) is a Port Harcourt–based visual artist working in photography, writing, and drawing. Her practice preserves culture and identity through surreal, chiaroscuro-inspired storytelling that explores femininity, beauty, and fashion. Influenced by cinema and baroque light-play, Kinika conveys emotion and cultural values with dramatic intensity. She has exhibited internationally, including Polaroid x Magnum at Paris Photo Fair, and participated in residencies such as Divergence, 1952 (Lagos) and Alternative Heritage (Ibadan).

item.title: Reem Aljeally
item.description: Reem Aljeally (b. 1997) is a multidisciplinary artist and curator. She is the founder of The Muse Multi Studios (2019) and The Sudan Art Archive (2022), supporting and preserving Sudanese visual arts. Her work in painting, installation, and printmaking explores movement, space, memory, and self-image. Aljeally has exhibited internationally and currently leads the Artists Development Program at Ubuntu Art Gallery in Cairo.

item.title: Haneem Christian
item.description: Haneem Christian is a Cape Town-based archivist and filmmaker whose lens-based practice explores Pan-African history through Queerness, centering community and African narratives. Their work has been shown at the International Cape Town Art Fair, 1-54 New York, AKAA, Latitudes, Unseen Photo Fair, and the National Portrait Gallery, London. Christian won the Pride Photo Award 2022, the Taylor Wessing National Portrait Award 2022, and a British Council Artist Grant, which funded their first docu-art film, Eyes to See, premiering at BFI Flare 2025. They have also completed a Magnum Photos residency, participated in a Nike campaign, and exhibited at the Cape Town International Art Fair.

item.title: Doaa Fakher
item.description: Doaa Fakher (b.1992, Cairo) is an Egyptian artist whose work explores human and societal issues through distorted, anonymous figures that reflect emotional and psychological states shaped by social injustice. Working in acrylic, oil, silkscreen, and sculpture, she uses the human body as a symbol of vulnerability and resilience. Fakher holds a BA in Art Education (Cairo University, 2012) and an MA in African Arts (Helwan University, 2020). Her work has been exhibited nationally and internationally, including AKAA Paris, 1-54 Contemporary African Art Fair, and the Luxor International Painting Symposium, and is in the Museum of Modern Egyptian Art collection. She is represented by Ubuntu Art Gallery, Cairo.

item.title: Dina Nomena
item.description: Dina Nomena Andriarimanjaka is a Malagasy visual artist, designer, and researcher whose transdisciplinary practice blends memory, textile, and resistance. Using embroidery, fabric remnants, and archival fragments, she explores women’s untold stories through a slow, layered process. Inspired by Malagasy heritage, matrimony, and cultural rituals, her work creates dialogue between past and present, and between individual and collective memory.

item.title: Brett Rubin
item.description: Brett Rubin (b.1982, Johannesburg) is a South African photographer and visual artist. He holds a graduate degree in Film, Media & Visual Studies from the University of Cape Town (2005). Rubin has worked across fashion, design, and portraiture, notably serving as the official photographer for jazz legend Hugh Masekela from 2012 until Masekela’s passing in 2018. His work explores portraiture, landscape, and the post-colonial figure, challenging conventional photographic methods. Rubin’s work has been exhibited locally and internationally, including at Design Indaba, Edinburgh International Art and Fashion Festival, Nirox Winter Sculpture Exhibition, and Southbank Centre, London.

item.title: Everard Read Gallery Johannesburg
item.description: Founded in 1913, Everard Read is Africa's oldest and largest commercial art gallery. For over a century, it has been a premier institution in the South African art world, dedicated to showcasing the country's finest contemporary artists. With seven distinct galleries across four key locations—Johannesburg, Cape Town, London, and Franschhoek—Everard Read offers an international platform for artists from diverse backgrounds. The gallery's mission is to support artists who are committed to contemporary storytelling, exceptional craft, and the making of meaning. It champions work that interrogates both universal and Afrocentric ideas, creating contemporary icons that inspire contemplation, introspection, and awe. Everard Read is committed to the long-term representation of exceptional, established voices while continuously seeking out and nurturing the next generation of talent, ensuring a dynamic and relevant program.

item.title: Amy Ayanda Studios
item.description: Amy Ayanda Lester (b. 1992) is a Cape Town-based artist and musician with an Honours degree in Painting from the Michaelis School of Fine Art, UCT. Her vibrant abstract works draw inspiration from the local landscape — its flora, colours, and people — while reflecting on her family’s history of forced removal from their flower farm during Apartheid. Exploring themes of memory, loss, and beauty, Lester’s intuitive use of colour captures emotion in its immediate, playful form. In 2024, she collaborated with printmaker Roxy Kaczmarek at the David Krut Workshop, created a series of vessels with Natasha Human, and presented new works at the Latitudes Art Fair.

item.title: BRUTAL.
item.description: Brutal. is a contemporary project space and gallery in Cape Town, founded by Elad Kirshenbaum and Norman O’Flynn in August 2020. Born from the challenging days of the COVID-19 pandemic, Brutal. is a multi-layered platform dedicated to a dynamic mix of emerging and established artists. More than a traditional gallery, Brutal. functions as an ecosystem, offering an artist residency, a mentorship program, and artist management facilities. Central to its identity is the BLACK CUBE project space, a direct response to the conventional 'white cube.' This flexible space embraces the raw, unfiltered energy of the city, championing art that is experimental, edgy, and boundary-pushing. The gallery's philosophy acknowledges that while the world can be brutal, this reality is met with a spirit of being brutally creative, brutally positive, and brutally in love with art.

item.title: Khaya Malinga
item.description: Khaya Malinga is a multidisciplinary artist whose practice spans painting, illustration, and digital media. His work explores themes of identity, memory, and everyday South African life, often blending realism with expressive abstraction. Malinga’s art captures intimate moments and emotional depth, reflecting his interest in storytelling through colour, form, and texture.

item.title: Linathi Makanda
item.description: Linathi Makanda is a South African multidisciplinary artist from Mthatha, Eastern Cape, working across photography, fine art, and poetry. Her work explores possibility, passion, and overlooked stories, often focusing on portraiture and still life with a strong sense of vulnerability. Makanda is a member of the global Black Women Photographers community, and her photography has been recognized internationally in Vogue Italia, Color Bloc Magazine, and Cardinal Sins. Her visual project Seasons has been featured in New Plains Review and screened at the Lift-Off Online Film Festival (UK). She is also the author of the poetry collection When No One Is Watching (Odyssey Books).

item.title: STILL Artist Residency
item.description: Founded by artist Ayana V. Jackson, the STILL Artist Residency supports primary care-giving, LGBTQIA+, and African diasporic artists—particularly from the SADC region—through time, space, and financial support to create new work. Based in Johannesburg’s Ellis House Art Building, the three-month residency provides studio space, stipends, and a supportive community. Rooted in an ethos of care, reflection, and sustainability, STILL fosters collaboration, creative growth, and amplifies underrepresented voices in contemporary art.

item.title: Bag Factory
item.description: Founded in 1991, Bag Factory is a non-profit contemporary visual arts organisation in Newtown, Johannesburg. It offers studio spaces for local artists, hosts international residencies and awards, and presents exhibitions that spotlight emerging talent. Affiliated with the Triangle Network, Bag Factory fosters cultural exchange, artistic experimentation, and community engagement through its diverse programmes and outreach initiatives.

item.title: Warren Editions
item.description: Warren Editions based in Capri as a Studios - Professional exhibitor and creative professional showcasing quality work, innovative designs, and artistic expertise in contemporary art, design, and cultural expression. Specializing in unique artistic vision and professional exhibition standards.

item.title: edition ~ verso
item.description: edition ~ verso, founded in 2015 by master printer Sara-Aimee Verity, is a Johannesburg-based fine art print studio and publishing platform dedicated to collaboration and technical excellence. Described as a “sensitive instrument,” the studio listens, interprets, and translates artists’ ideas into print, fostering experimentation and innovation in the medium. The women-led team—Verity, Megan Rumpelt, Courteney Bentley, and Michaela Verity—works within an intimate, contemplative environment, offering a full range of printmaking techniques including intaglio, relief, collograph, chine collé, and monotype, alongside handmade paper production from studio waste. edition ~ verso has collaborated with leading artists such as Thenjiwe Nkosi, Gabrielle Goliath, Donna Kukama, Felix Shumba, and Lindokuhle Sobekwa, cultivating long-term partnerships that allow artists to explore print as an extension of their practice. The studio also runs an active internship programme, training emerging printmakers and arts professionals.

item.title: Property of Studio
item.description: Property Of Studio is a contemporary art space dedicated to championing emerging and mid-career artists across diverse mediums. Located in a vibrant cultural hub, it serves as both a space for artistic exploration and a platform for dialogue between artists, collectors, and audiences. Through curated exhibitions and collaborative projects, the studio highlights storytelling that connects personal vision with broader social and cultural themes. With a dynamic mix of physical and digital exhibitions, Property Of Studio is committed to accessibility, authenticity, and innovation—bridging the gap between artistic intent and audience engagement while redefining the contemporary art experience.

item.title: Themba Sibeko
item.description: Themba Sibeko based in Johannesburg as a Independent Artist - Professional exhibitor and creative professional showcasing quality work, innovative designs, and artistic expertise in contemporary art, design, and cultural expression. Specializing in unique artistic vision and professional exhibition standards.

item.title: Stephen Tapestry Studio
item.description: Founded in the early 1960s by Coral Stephens, Stephens Tapestry Studio is South Africa’s leading hand-weaving atelier, dedicated to preserving and advancing the art of tapestry. The studio's story is one of a creative spirit passed down as a matrilineal inheretence. From the very first artistic tapestry of a Cecil Skotness woodblock, woven by Coral's daughter Marguerite Stephens, the studio expanded its collaborators to more South African and later international artists. Known for its collaborative approach, the studio works closely with artists to translate original designs into richly textured, large-scale woven works. Each tapestry is a testament to the skill, patience, and interpretive artistry of its weavers, continuing a legacy of excellence and resilience that spans over six decades.

item.title: Andiswa Bhungane
item.description: Andiswa Bhungane based in Johannesburg as a Independent Artist - Professional exhibitor and creative professional showcasing quality work, innovative designs, and artistic expertise in contemporary art, design, and cultural expression. Specializing in unique artistic vision and professional exhibition standards.

item.title: eComplete Exhibition 2

item.title: Lucky + Me
item.description: Nestled in the heart of Douala, Cameroon's bustling economic and cultural capital, Logmo + Makon stands as a dynamic institution passionately dedicated to the vibrant, complex, and evolving landscape of contemporary African art. Founded with a clear vision, we are more than just a gallery; we are a dedicated champion and a nurturing platform for the artists who are defining the continent's modern creative identity. Our core mission is to seek out, support, and actively promote a diverse roster of creators, encompassing both emerging talents taking their first audacious steps and established artists whose practices have already shaped critical conversations. We are drawn to work that is intellectually rigorous and aesthetically compelling—art that refuses to be silent. The common thread connecting our artists is a profound and critical engagement with the pressing social, political, and cultural realities of our time. Their practices delve into the intricate layers of contemporary life, from the rapid pace of urbanization and the complexities of post-colonial identity to the impacts of globalization, digital transformation, and environmental change. In a world too often reliant on singular or outdated narratives about Africa, Logmo + Makon is committed to fostering the bold artistic voices that are actively shaping new, nuanced, and multifaceted perspectives. We believe in the transformative power of art to dismantle stereotypes, challenge entrenched assumptions, and fundamentally broaden the horizons of all who engage with it. We proudly position ourselves as a vital conduit—a bridge connecting the fertile ground of local creativity in Douala and across the continent with the expansive international art scene. Through thoughtfully curated exhibitions, participation in global art fairs, and strategic partnerships with institutions, we work tirelessly to ensure that the powerful stories and unique visions of our artists resonate with a global audience. Logmo + Makon is intentionally designed as a space of dialogue, intellectual exchange, and community. We transcend the traditional "white cube" model to become a gathering place for artists, collectors, curators, scholars, and art lovers to connect. Here, art becomes the catalyst for essential conversations—a universal language that builds understanding and paves the way for the future of the continent.
